{"order": 2, "remote_id": null, "dummy": false, "slug": "methods-of-facilitating-change", "code": "MEFC", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>The use of simple tools and guides, that have been specifically designed to direct the user towards more sustainable choices, can provide an everyday way to incorporate green chemistry thinking into bench-scale research.&nbsp; They are particularly useful for example in medicinal chemistry, where multiple routes to numerous different compounds are under consideration at the same time and more detailed assessment (e.g. life cycle assessment) would be unfeasible due to time constraints.&nbsp;</p>\r\n<p>These quick and easy to use guides support the reduction of potential adverse environmental impact of reactions, as well as helping to minimise the need for major changes to synthetic routes that are scaled-up for further development.</p>\r\n<p>Whilst it is important to have a sound understanding of issues and the wider implications surrounding the chemicals you use in your research, it is not necessarily practical to spend significant amounts of time analysing each individual substance. &nbsp;One of the advantages of using selection guides is that the data collection and analysis has already been performed. &nbsp;The individual ranking or grouping within the guides allows you to make an informed decision as to the most appropriate choice for your needs.</p>\r\n<p>This topic will provide an overview of existing solvent and reagent selection tools and guides.</p>\r\n<h3>Learning objectives</h3>\r\n<p><em>By the end of this module you should, for each type of selection tool we discuss:</em></p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li><span>Understand why they have been developed</span></li>\r\n<li><span>Understand their benefits and limitations</span></li>\r\n<li><span>Understand the criteria used in developing the tools</span></li>\r\n<li><span>Know where to find them</span></li>\r\n<li><span>Be able to describe a typical use</span></li>\r\n<li><span>Be able to use them in specific case studies</span></li>\r\n</ul>", "name": "Guides and metrics", "dirty": "[\"id\", \"title\"]", "changed": false}, "model": "repo.topic", products to degrade at a reasonable rate after use, so that they do not accumulate in the environment and are inherently 'benign by design'.&nbsp; Designing drugs that are degradable is however not a straightforward issue as the biological activity of a pharmaceutical compound is dependent upon its precise chemical structure and must also have the correct level of stability and a reasonable shelf life. &nbsp;This Module looks at this issue in more depth and explores the scope for minimising the environmental impact of APIs.</p>\r\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\r\n<p><strong>Learning \"klass\"]", "changed": false}, "model": "repo.module", "pk": 19}, {"fields": {"order": 12, "remote_id": 193, "dummy": false, "slug": "biocatalysis", "working": false, "code": "WP3", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>The tools of modern molecular biology have led to an explosion in the number and range of biocatalysts available for use. Bespoke recombinant mutant enzymes for organic synthesis can now be rapidly developed and biocatalysis is now an underpinning part of the green chemistry tool box to enable safe and low environmental impact synthesis. &nbsp;Many classes of enzyme of interest to the synthetic organic chemist are now available commercially. &nbsp;Biocatalysis can provide unique catalytic opportunities not accessible with conventional chemistry and can also facilitate efficient shorter routes to complex chiral intermediates.</p><p>Whilst biocatalysts may offer various advantages over conventional routes, one should also be aware that significant lifecycle burdens are often generated during the downstream processes for bio-reactions [bib]10.1007/s11367-009-0081-9[/bib]. &nbsp;The product streams from bio-reactions are typically dilute aqueous solutions, which can bring specific problems that need to be addressed from both an environmental and process optimisation standpoint. &nbsp;For example large amounts of organic solvents may be used for extraction [bib]10.1016/j.compchemeng.2010.03.010[/bib]. &nbsp;All new methodologies developed should be assessed from a holistic perspective; in order to ensure that potential environmental \u2018hotspots\u2019 are not missed downstream from the actual synthetic step: see <a href=\"/node/110\">Topic 2: Metrics</a> for further study on holistic assessment of methodologies.&nbsp;</p><h3>Recommended further reading</h3><ul><li><span>[ibib]ebook15[/ibib]</span></li><li>[ibib]10.1039/C2CS15286J[/ibib]</li><li>[ibib]10.1016/j.cbpa.2013.01.017[/ibib]</li></ul><h3>Learning objectives</h3><p>By the end of this module you should:</p><ul><li><span>Be aware of the concept of biocatalytic retrosynthesis and the potential of enzyme catalysts to offer assistance in synthetic chemistry</span></li><li><span>Understand how enzyme catalysts can be as applied to the synthesis of certain target molecules and functional groups</span></li><li><span>Be able to consider explain:</p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>why solvent selection guides are needed in the pharmaceutical industry</li>\r\n<li>the criteria used in devising such guides, and the resulting benefits and "remote_id": 435, "dummy": false, "slug": "route-selection", "working": false, "code": "ROSE", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p class=\"Default\">The concept of the CHEM21 project is to develop an improved \u2018sustainable chemistry\u2019 tool\u2013box with new synthetic methods for the manufacture of APIs that are more sustainable and efficient than the existing ones and that provide solutions to current \u2018bottlenecks\u2019.&nbsp; CHEM21 is unique in that it links leading academics in the field of green chemistry, chemical catalysis and synthetic biology with scientists working on small molecule API discovery and manufacture within the pharmaceutical industry to tackle the challenges found in the commercial manufacture of drugs.&nbsp; This topic will provide examples of new, greener methodologies that can be applied to the synthesis of APIs, intermediates and other molecules, with case-studies of CHEM21 originated research as well as literature examples.</p><p class=\"Default\">Other up-to-date sources of information on \u2018greener methodologies\u2019, particularly of relevance to the pharmaceutical industry include the biannual reviews co-authored by ACS Green Chemistry Institute (GCI) Pharmaceutical Roundtable (ACS GCIPR) members on \u2018Green Chemistry Articles of Interest to the Pharmaceutical Industry\u2019. These papers focus on very recent advances in key research areas/transformations relevant to pharmaceutical synthesis, for example solvents, amide formation, oxidations, C-H activation, biocatalysis and process intensification. (Org. Process Res. Dev., 2013, 17, (4), 615<a id=\"_anchor_1\" href=\"file:///Z:/CHEM21/Education%20and%20Training%20Material/Topic%204/Overall%20structure%20for%20Topic%204.docx#_msocom_1\" language=\"JavaScript\" name=\"_msoanchor_1\">[LS1]</a>&nbsp;).&nbsp; The ACS GCIPR also disseminates current publications on the subject of greening pharmaceuticals via their website (<a href=\"http://www.acs.org/content/acs/en/greenchemistry/industry-business/pharmaceutical.html\">http://www.acs.org/content/acs/en/greenchemistry/industry-business/pharmaceutical.html</a>).</p>", "name": "Route selection", "topic": 4, "dirty": "[\"lesson_orders\", \"intro\", \"klass\"]", "changed": false}, "model": "repo.module", "pk": 28}, {"fields": {"order": 17, "remote_id": 430, "dummy": false, "slug": "amidation", "working": false, "code": "AMID", "order_dirty": true, "text": null, "name": "Amidation", "topic": 4, "dirty": "[\"klass\", \"intro\"]", "changed": false}, "model": "repo.module", "pk": 29}, {"fields": {"order": 14, "remote_id": 404, "dummy": false, "slug": "c-h-activation", "working": false, "code": "CHAC", "order_dirty": true, "text": "", "name": "C-H activation", "topic": 4, "dirty": "[\"klass\", \"intro\", \"title\"]", "changed": false}, "model": "repo.module", "pk": 30}, {"fields": {"order": 15, "remote_id": 465, "dummy": false, "slug": "c-x-bond-formation", "working": false, "code": "CXBO", "order_dirty": true, "text": "", "name": "C-F bond formation", "topic": 4, "dirty": "[\"klass\", \"intro\", \"title\"]", "changed": false}, "model": "repo.module", "pk": 31}, {"fields": {"order": 13, "remote_id": 388, "dummy": false, "slug": "multicomponent-reactions", "working": false, "code": "MULR", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>MCRs (multicomponent reactions) are a valuable strategy in the \u2018green chemistry toolbox\u2019 when designing a synthetic approach with sustainability in mind and are increasingly growing in application in medicinal chemistry and drug discovery programmes, combinatorial chemistry, natural product synthesis, and polymer chemistry.1 They also are ideally suited for diversity oriented synthesis and library generation.&nbsp; In 2014 R. C. Cioc, E. Ruijter &amp; R. V. A. Orru published a review to promote the green process design opportunities available through the application of MCRs.1&nbsp; You can read the full paper here (<a href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1039/c4gc00013g\">http://dx.doi.org/10.1039/c4gc00013g</a>).</p><p>The benefits of MCRs are that they bring together at least three reactants in one-pot bringing about an efficient and intrinsically atom economical reaction (generating a product that contains essentially all the atoms of the starting materials), generally under mild conditions and frequently using greener solvents.1</p><p>A major advantage of MCRs is <em>waste reduction</em> \u2013 due to their highly convergent nature, MCRs reduce waste generated by a process by incorporating a highly resource efficient step in the synthesis and often shortening the overall number of steps.&nbsp;&nbsp; Their excellent chemo-and regio-selectivity minimises the generation of side-products, and by products are typically simple, small molecules such as water, alcohols, amines or common salts, resulting in not only&nbsp; a reduced amount of waste, but the waste itself is generally benign (avoiding problems associated with the recovery and disposal of hazardous waste).&nbsp; The work-up of these reactions is often straightforward via precipitation of the product, avoiding the use of more time consuming and resource intensive recovery and purification methods.&nbsp; Solvent use is also generally significantly reduced due to reaction telescoping and improved work-up.</p><p>Table 1 demonstrates some representative examples of MCRs and some indicative green chemistry metrics.</p><p>[figure:show:235]</p><p>Reproduced from Cioc, R. C.; Ruijter, E.&amp; Orru, R. V. A., Multicomponent reactions: advanced tools for sustainable organic synthesis, <em>Green Chem</em>., <strong>2014</strong>, <em>16,</em> 2958-2975 with permission of The Royal Society of Chemistry (<a href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1039/c4gc00013g\">http://dx.doi.org/10.1039/c4gc00013g</a>)</p><p>One issue with the MCRs is that a number of the MCR strategies use a cyanide or an isocyanide as one of the reaction components, the synthesis of which are typically themselves atom-inefficient and tend to use hazardous reagents and problematic solvents and as such the environmental implications of the preparation of these compounds must be taken into consideration (as well as the toxicity of the cyanide compounds). This reinforces the importance of looking upstream and downstream of a particular reaction step and thinking holistically to ensure that methodologies are genuinely greener.&nbsp; Research is underway to explore more environmentally acceptable methods of generating cyanides, for example the use of potassium hexacyanoferrate (II) as an environmentally benign cyanide source3,4.</p><p>&nbsp;</p>", "name": "Multicomponent reactions", "topic": 4, "dirty": "[\"klass\"]", "changed": false}, "model": "repo.module", "pk": 34}, {"fields": {"order": 10, "remote_id": 579, "dummy": false, "slug": "green-solvent-methods", "working": true, "code": "SMETH", "order_dirty": true, "text": null, "name": "Green solvent methods", "topic": 6, "dirty": "[\"klass\", \"intro\"]", "changed": false}, "model": "repo.module", "pk": 38}, {"fields": {"order": 9, "remote_id": 560, "dummy": false, "slug": "use-of-solvents", "working": false, "code": "SOLVU", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p class=\"MsoNormal\"><i>By the end of this module you should:</i></p><ul><li><span style=\"line-height: 1.5; etc.</li><li>End-of-life impacts \u2013 this essentially relates to what happens to the API molecule post-patient and its effects in the environment, which can be subdivided into:<ul><li>Potential issues with contamination of human drinking water with APIs and their residues</li><li>The effects on organisms other than humans exposed to the APIs and their residues in water courses</li></ul></li></ul><p>Life cycle analysis (LCA) and the need to consider all components of the manufacturing process is covered in more detail in Topic 2 [TODO: link] of this material.&nbsp; However in the first section of this topic we will discuss whole-process LCA briefly, focussing on carbon footprint, with illustrative examples from the pharmaceutical industry.</p><p>This is followed by a short discussion on secondary manufacturing and packaging (point 1 above.)</p><p>The rest of this section, and this topic overall, will then focus on end-of-life impacts (point 2 above.)</p>", "name": "Examining the life cycle", "topic": 3, "dirty": "[\"klass\", \"intro\"]", "changed": false}, "model": "repo.module", "pk": 40}, {"fields": {"order": 22, "remote_id": 594, "dummy": false, "slug": "the-fate-of-apis", "working": false, "code": "FATE", "order_dirty": true, "text": null, "name": "The fate of APIs", "topic": 3, "dirty": "[\"klass\", \"intro\"]", "changed": false}, "model": "repo.module", "pk": 41}, {"fields": {"order": 23, "remote_id": 615, "dummy": false, "slug": "regulatory-and-safety-issues", "working": false, "code": "REDB", "order_dirty": true, "text": null, "name": "Regulatory and Safety Issues", "topic": 3, "dirty": "[\"klass\", \"intro\"]", "changed": false}, "model": "repo.module", "pk": 42}, {"fields": {"order": 25, "remote_id": 0, "dummy": false, "slug": "summary-further-reading", "working": false, "code": "CSUMM", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>In an ideal situation, an API molecule would be stable during processing and formulation, stable for many years at a range of temperatures and humidities, active and efficacious when taken by the patient; and then be completely metabolised or decomposed in the environment on excretion, into innocuous substances. In practice, this is very difficult to achieve and represents somewhat of a utopian situation; this is now being recognised by the stakeholders in the pharmaceutical industry. If some APIs can be designed in that way in the future, it would represent an ideal scenario but is very unlikely to be the case for all small molecules. Additionally of course, it would not solve the issue of the persistence of many of the current treatments, which will continue to be used for the foreseeable future.</p>\r\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\r\n<p><strong>Recommended further reading</strong></p>\r\n<p>K. "order_dirty": false, "text": "<p>Biocatalysis can present a number of advantages including reduced cost of goods, improved environmental impact, better safety profiles, improved step and atom economy and reduced solvent usage, all of which can contribute to more sustainable manufacturing processes. &nbsp;A major development in the field of biocatalysis is the impact that protein engineering and directed evolution have made on the properties of biocatalysts. &nbsp;Another, relatively new concept is that of designing new synthetic routes to targte molecules using &nbsp;\u2018biocatalytic retrosynthesis\u2019 . &nbsp;With biocatalytic retrosynthesis, molecules are disconnected in a different way than if solely chemical reagents are relied upon leading to the development of new pathways 1</a> where the different enzyme classes and their mechanisms were discussed, this lesson looks at the use of these enzymes in the synthesis of certain target molecules and functional groups. "order_dirty": false, "text": "<p>In this lesson we will look at some examples where biocatalysis has been employed for the synthesis of Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients (APIs). &nbsp;This will demonstrate the potential impact of biocatalysis in the pharmaceutical industry, in terms of a move towards lower environmental impact manufacturing processes, as well as making important medicines on {"order": 0, "modules": [], "remote_id": null, "dummy": false, "slug": "summary-and-further-reading", "order_dirty": true, "text": "", "title": "Summary and further reading", "dirty": "[\"question_orders\", \"id\"]", "changed": false}, "model": "repo.lesson", "pk": 111}, {"fields": {"order": 6, "modules": [19], "remote_id": null, "dummy": false, "slug": "introduction-to-catalysis", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>&nbsp;Catalysis is one of the overarching principles of green chemistry capable of producing substantial material and energy savings as well as economic benefits.&nbsp; When comparing catalytic methods to traditional stoichiometric syntheses, catalysis offers undisputable economy in reagent use. Stoichiometric reactions would require at least one mole of reagent per mole of starting material, whereas a catalyst, subject to turnover number (TON), can carry out a transformation multiple times per mole of catalyst.&nbsp; Catalytic reagents can be used to improve product selectivity, by enabling diastereomeric control and site specific transformations in multi-functionalised molecules.&nbsp; Moreover catalysts allow reactions to proceed under milder reaction conditions. Moreover, catalytic methods can circumvent the need for pre-functionalisation of the starting materials with activating or directing groups, which would later need to be removed from the final molecule. Thus the use of catalytic rather than stoichiometric methods can dramatically enhance the atom economy of a synthesis, save time and energy, as well as decreasing the amount of raw materials consumed and waste generated. The development and application of catalytic methods can significantly improve both the economic and environmental profile when designing synthetic routes within process research and development (R&amp;D).&nbsp; (H.-J. Federsel,<em> Drug Discovery Today</em>, 2006, <strong>11</strong>, 966). &nbsp;</p>\r\n<p>&nbsp;There are several factors to consider when selecting a catalyst in terms of its green credentials, including:</p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>Catalyst efficacy eg. product yield, Turnover number (TON), space-time yield etc</li>\r\n<li>Homogeneous or heterogeneous catalysts: while homogeneous catalysis tends to afford high activity and selectivity, heterogeneous systems benefit from ease of operational use and catalyst recovery and recycling, which has obvious advantages in economy and sustainability. Catalysts can be heterogenised by the entrapping or grafting of the active molecules onto the surfaces or pores of solid supports such silica, alumina and ceria among others (Also known as immobilised catalysts)</li>\r\n<li>Chemical catalysts vs biological catalysts (enzymes). Chemical catalysts can often rely on the usage of rare and precious heavy metals (see [TODO: link] Critical Elements section) to achieve the desired chemistry whilst biological catalysts can require dilute conditions and operate under a smaller range of solvents.</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n<p><br />As catalysts play a crucial role in synthetic chemistry, they will be covered in more detail in [TODO: link]Topic 4, the Synthetic Toolbox, whilst methods for objectively measuring greenness will be covered in the [TODO: link] metrics section.&nbsp;<br /><br /><strong>Sources and further reading</strong></p>\r\n<p><br />Andrew Hunt et al, Sustainable Catalysis: With Non-endangered Metals, Parts 1 and 2, Royal Society of Chemistry; Gld edition (Nov. 16 2015), ISBN: 978-1-782-62056-3<br />Paul Anastas &amp; Robert Crabtree, Handbook of Green Chemistry, 3 Volume Set, Green Catalysis, Wiley (2009), ISBN: 978-3-527-31577-2<br />Roger Sheldon, Isabel Arends &amp; Ulf Hanefield, Green Chemistry and Catalysis, Wiley-VCH (2007), ISBN: 978-3-257-80715-9<br />http://scienceaid.co.uk/chemistry/inorganic/catalysis.html<br />http://www.chemguide.co.uk/physical/catalysismenu.html<br /><br /></p>", "title": "Introduction to catalysis", "dirty": "[\"question_orders\", \"id\"]", "changed": false}, "model": "repo.lesson", "pk": 112}, {"fields": {"order": 7, "modules": [19], "remote_id": "pk": 35}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 3, "remote_id": 118, "dummy": false, "slug": "toolkit-interpretation", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<div class=\"reaction-discovery\" data-stage=\"0\"><h2>Reaction discovery: zero pass</h2><p>Use at reaction discovery level- reaction screening at mg scale.</p><p>Most promising reactions as indicated by your green metrics can then be taken to first pass and beyond.</p><div class=\"intro\"><h3>Yield, conversion and selectivity</h3><ul><li>High yield is desirable</li><li>If yield is low but conversion is high- reaction requires optimisation</li><li>If yield is low and conversion is low- reaction requires redesign</li></ul></div><table class=\"flow-chart\"><tbody><tr><th colspan=\"3\">Yield, Conversion and Selectivity<br /> Considers limiting reactant and product</th></tr><tr class=\"choice\"><td class=\"good\">Yield is high</td><td class=\"ok\">Yield low but selectivity high (low conversion)</td><td class=\"bad\">Yield low and selectivity low (high conversion)</td></tr><tr class=\"outcome\"><td class=\"success\">\u2714</td><td class=\"amend\">Reaction can be optimised</td><td class=\"fail\">You need to return to your reaction and redesign it</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"reaction-discovery\" data-stage=\"1\"><div class=\"intro\"><h3>Atom Economy and Reaction Mass Efficiency</h3><ul><li><span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\">&nbsp;Atom Economy (AE) measures the efficiency of the reaction by the number of the atoms from the reactants that appear in the final product.</span></li><li><span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\">AE assumes 100% yield and stoichiometric loading</span></li><li><span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\">AE is an excellent metric to access the inherent efficiency of a reaction with respect to use of reactants- however is not great as a standalone metric</span></li><li><span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\">Reaction Mass Efficiency (RME) gives a fuller picture of reactant use- It is mass based and incorporates yield and stoichiometry</span></li><li><span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"></span><b style=\"line-height: 1.5;\">According to Andraos: a reaction is only considered green when both the AE and RME are above 62% <i>i.e</i></b> <span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"></span><b style=\"line-height: 1.5;\">if a reaction has an RME of \u226562% but an AE of&nbsp; less than 62% or vice versa - the reaction is <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">not</span></b> <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><b>green</b></span></li><li><b style=\"line-height: 1.5;\">However, if your AE and RME are much greater than the current state of the art, then you are well on your way to improving the green credentials of such transformations</b></li><li><span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\">The AE provides the optimum efficiency your process can achieve- the closer the RME is to it, the closer the reaction is to its optimal efficiency.</span> <b style=\"line-height: 1.5;\">&nbsp;</b><span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\">&nbsp;</span></li></ul></div><table class=\"flow-chart\"><tbody><tr><th colspan=\"2\">Atom economy<br /> Considers all reactants<br /> Assumes 100% yield</th></tr><tr class=\"choice\"><td class=\"good\">Atom economy high (\u2265 62%)</td><td class=\"ok\">Atom economy low</td></tr><tr class=\"outcome\"><td class=\"success\">\u2714</td><td class=\"amend\">Maximise incorporation of starting material into product (fewer wasted atoms).<br /> Choose leaving groups to be as small as possible, avoid large protecting groups..</td></tr></tbody></table><table class=\"flow-chart\"><tbody><tr><th colspan=\"2\">Reaction mass efficiency<br /> Considers all reactants, stoichiometries and yield<br /> The most efficient your reaction can be is if RME=AE</th></tr><tr class=\"choice\"><td class=\"good\">RME (\u226562%) ~ AE</td><td class=\"ok\">RME &lt;&lt; AE</td></tr><tr class=\"outcome\"><td class=\"success\">\u2714</td><td class=\"amend\">Try to reduce stoichiometric loading of reagents whilst monitoring yield</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"reaction-discovery\" data-stage=\"2\"><div class=\"intro\"><h3 class=\"MsoSubtitle\">Solvents</h3><p class=\"MsoListParagraphCxSpFirst\" style=\"text-indent: -18.0pt; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1;\"></p><ul><li><span style=\"text-indent: -18pt; line-height: 1.5;\"></span><span style=\"text-indent: -18pt; font-stretch: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-family: 'Times New Roman';\"></span><span style=\"text-indent: -18pt; line-height: 1.5;\">At reaction discovery stage is clearly important to allow for screening for as broad a range of solvents as possible</span></li><li><span style=\"text-indent: -18pt; line-height: 1.5;\"></span><span style=\"text-indent: -18pt; line-height: 1.5;\">This will help determine the best solvent and best solvent properties for the reaction</span></li><li><span style=\"text-indent: -18pt; line-height: 1.5;\"></span><span style=\"text-indent: -18pt; line-height: 1.5;\">Which will come in handy if the optimum solvent you have selected for the reaction is highly undesirable- restricted by OPRD and REACH- which will give you a red a flag</span></li><li><span style=\"text-indent: -18pt; line-height: 1.5;\"></span><span style=\"text-indent: -18pt; line-height: 1.5;\">In this situation, use of solvent maps could help you find a greener solvent alternative to screen for.&nbsp;</span></li></ul><!--[if !supportLists]--><p></p><p class=\"MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle\" style=\"text-indent: -18.0pt; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1;\"></p><p class=\"MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle\" style=\"text-indent: -18.0pt; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1;\"></p><p></p><p class=\"MsoListParagraphCxSpLast\" style=\"text-indent: -18.0pt; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1;\"></p></div><table class=\"flow-chart\"><tbody><tr><th colspan=\"2\">Solvents</th></tr></tbody><tbody><tr class=\"choice\"><td class=\"good\">No highly undesirable solvents</td><td class=\"ok\">Black listed solvents used</td></tr><tr class=\"outcome\"><td class=\"success\">\u2714</td><td class=\"amend\">Do not use! Use CHEM21 solvent replacement guides to identify a potential replacement</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"reaction-discovery\" data-stage=\"3\"><div class=\"intro\"><h3>Health and Safety</h3><ul><li><span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\">&nbsp;Screening for a broad range of reagents is also necessary at this stage and give a lot of insight into the chemical transformation</span></li><li><span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\">As such only the most severe hazard statements (red flag) are to be avoided at zero pass and must be substituted</span></li></ul></div><table class=\"flow-chart\"><tbody><tr><th colspan=\"2\">Health and safety<br /> Red-flagged substances carry a serious physical, health or environmental Although issues such as by-product formation and elemental sustainability are not incorporated, there are plans to include Reaction Mass Efficiency and other considerations in future to update these guides. The guides provide a sound and easy to access reference particularly for bench chemists to encourage use of greener reagents.<br /><span></span></p><p></p>", "title": "GSK reagent selection guides", "dirty": "[\"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [11]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 47}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1459], "order": 0, "remote_id": 32, "dummy": false, "slug": "gsk-example-oxidation-to-aldehydes-and-ketones", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<ul><li>The <a href=\"http://www.rsc.org/suppdata/gc/c3/c3gc40225h/c3gc40225h.pdf\">GSK reagent guides</a></li></ul>", "title": "GSK example: oxidation to aldehydes and ketones", "dirty": "[\"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [11]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 48}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1461], "order": 0, "remote_id": 33, "dummy": false, "slug": "gsk-example-reductive-amination", "order_dirty": true, "text": null, "title": "GSK example: reductive amination", "dirty": "[\"intro\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [11]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 49}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 0, "remote_id": 62, "dummy": false, "slug": "gsk-acid-and-base-selection-guides", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>A set of <a href=\"http://www.rsc.org/suppdata/gc/c4/c4gc01481b/c4gc01481b1.pdf\">Acid and Base Selection guides</a> have been developed by GlaxoSmithKline [bib]10.1039/C4GC01481B[/bib] using the same methodology that was applied to develop their reagent guides .&nbsp; Factors such as solubility, boiling point, ease of handling and EHS considerations should all be taken into account when selecting the correct acid or base to use for a particular transformation, and the user may sometimes be limited to a small number of options.&nbsp;</p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>Where a range of options for the choice of acid or base are available, these guides can direct the user to more sustainable alternatives.&nbsp;&nbsp; Importantly, these guides also include the pKa&nbsp; data for all of the individual acids and bases.</li>\r\n<li>Where choice is limited, the guides can also help the user to differentiate between a class of acids or bases based on their sustainability.</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n<p>Scoring includes consideration of concerns arising from, for example, the generation of gaseous, flammable or toxic by-products or the disposal via incineration for halogenated acids, via incorporation in the &lsquo;Chemistry Score&rsquo;.&nbsp; These issues have the potential to cause significant problems if the chemistry is to be performed on a larger scale.&nbsp; LCA and waste disposal would also need to be taken into consideration in the case of using an acid or a base as a solvent. #</p>\r\n<p><strong>Figure reproduced from R. K. Henderson, Hill, A. P. , Redman, A. M. and Sneddon, H. This tool provides rapidly accessible information to select efficient green transformations by grading reagents using three criteria: greenness, performance and scalability and is visually represented in the form of Venn diagrams. Access to this tool is however not freely available, although examples of reagents for the oxidation of primary alcohol to aldehyde and amide formation from acids are included in the paper. [bib]10.1039/B711717E[/bib]. The Pfizer reagent guide concept is currently being developed by the ACS GCI Pharma Roundtable, although the data is limited to Roundtable members, this may change in the future.</p><p></p>", "title": "Pfizer selection guide", "dirty": "[\"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [11]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 51}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 1, "remote_id": 42, "dummy": true, "slug": "question-1", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Read the experimental section of the following paper on the synthesis of Rabeprazole:&nbsp;</p><p>[ibib]166[/ibib]</p><p><span>The improved version provides superior yield, atom economies, reaction mass efficiencies and process mass intensities to the patented version. However there are still areas of improvement. Using the CHEM21 solvent selection guide, identify the solvents of major issues to be substituted. [bib]102[/bib] &nbsp;These principles focus on how to make a greener synthetic process, chemical product or chemical reaction, resulting in minimising its environmental impact.</p>\r\n<p>[greenprinciple:show]</p>\r\n<p><span>The twelve principles gained prominence in 1998 but as the scope of green chemistry has broadened, so have the potential applications.&nbsp;</span>This is explored further in the lesson&nbsp;<a href=\"../../../../node/90\">Twelve principles for the twenty-first century</a>.</p>\r\n<p>Resources:</p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/user/GreenChemUofT/videos\">Green Chemistry Initiative, University of Toronto: video series on the 12 principles</a>, written by students for students</li>\r\n<li><a href=\"http://www.acs.org/content/acs/en/greenchemistry/what-is-green-chemistry/principles/12-principles-of-green-chemistry.html\">ACS GCI PR statement of the principles</a> with accompanying commentary from experts in each area</li>\r\n</ul>", "title": "Green chemistry", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [17]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 54}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 1, "remote_id": 100, "dummy": false, "slug": "green-engineering", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p><span>Green engineering can be defined as the design, commercialisation and use of processes and products that are feasible and economical while minimising generation of pollution at source, and risk to human health and the environment [bib]10.1021/es032633u[/bib].</span></p>\r\n<p><span>Green engineering&nbsp;</span>uses the tools of recycling, process intensification and design optimisation to maximise the efficiency of a process, and reduce its negative impact on the environment. This approach&nbsp;evaluates the manufacturing process as a system and seeks to optimise its design, and in the truest sense, incorporates the concepts of life-cycle analysis and environmental economics into an appropriate evaluation of the overall environmental impact. The development of a set of metrics is required that appropriately evaluates the environmental parameters that we seek to control.&nbsp;</p>", "title": "Green engineering", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [17]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 55}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 2, "remote_id": 101, "dummy": false, "slug": "sustainable-design", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p><span>Sustainable design looks out even more broadly to try to understand the relationships between the manufacturing system and the ecosystem.<br /></span></p>\r\n<p><span>Sustainability&nbsp;</span>focuses on the triple bottom line: the integration of ecological integrity, societal responsibility and economic viability. This applies&nbsp;the broadest level systems approach, looking at the planet as the system of interest.</p>\r\n<p><span>In order to optimise design at this scale, new ways of measuring human impacts on the environment will be required.</span></p>", "title": "Sustainable design", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [17]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 56}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1476], "order": 1, "remote_id": 95, "dummy": false, "slug": "how-the-principles-look-today", "order_dirty": true, "text": "", "title": "How the principles look today", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": []}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 57}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1227, 1428], "order": 3, "remote_id": 96, "dummy": false, "slug": "misunderstandings-of-green-chemistry", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>It is helpful when learning about the foundations of modern green chemistry to look at some common misconceptions and how chemists in the area are working to counteract them. {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 1, "remote_id": 183, "dummy": false, "slug": "overview-and-history", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>The field of Green Chemistry has evolved over the decades. In the 1980s, the focus was on pollution control, with the publication of the 12 principles of green chemistry&nbsp;[bib]102[/bib]&nbsp;in the late 1990s encouraging a more holistic approach, through to the 2010s, which has seen an explosion in the number of publications claiming to include green reaction processes&nbsp;[bib]10.1007/s10698-009-9079-4[/bib]. &nbsp;Answering the question as to whether a reaction is genuinely &lsquo;green&rsquo; is not straightforward and requires an objective method of measuring its environmental impact.</p>\r\n<p>In order to assess the greenness of a reaction, a number of &lsquo;green metrics&rsquo; have been developed, which allow chemists to quantify and qualify the environmental impact of their reactions and assist with the comparison of different routes/methods. &nbsp;Early green metrics focused largely on efficiencies in terms of mass inputs and outputs, but this has since expanded to incorporate a much more comprehensive and holistic approach. &nbsp;The following references provide an excellent overview of available green chemistry metrics:</p>\r\n<p>[ibib]10.1039/B206169B[/ibib]</p>\r\n<p>[ibib]10.1039/C1CS15215G[/ibib]</p>\r\n<p>&nbsp;</p>", "title": "Overview and history", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [20]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 63}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 2, "remote_id": 184, "dummy": false, "slug": "the-chem21-toolkit", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>The CHEM21 project has developed a unified metrics toolkit to comprehensively evaluate the sustainability of chemical and bio-chemical reactions based on a series of key parameters (see figure 1). Moving beyond the use of &lsquo;mass based metrics&rsquo; alone, the toolkit uses a blend of both qualitative and quantitative criteria to assess how green a reaction is, as well as considering factors both upstream and downstream of the reaction itself. This ensures a truly holistic approach.</p>\r\n<p><span>The rationale behind the toolkit and the methodology employed is now available in an open access publication [bib]10.1039/C5GC00340G[/bib]</span><span>. As part of the background to this work CHEM21 performed a survey of available Green Chemistry metrics, which is accessible within the </span><a href=\"http://www.rsc.org/suppdata/c5/gc/c5gc00340g/c5gc00340g2.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">supplementary information</a><span> of this paper.</span></p>\r\n<p><em>For further study of green metrics, see the topic 2 module&nbsp;<a href=\"../../../../node/110\">Metrics</a>&nbsp;.</em></p>", "title": "The CHEM21 toolkit", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [20]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 64}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 1, "remote_id": 108, "dummy": false, "slug": "worldwide-initiatives", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>As has been discussed, increasing legislation, limited resources and changes in scientific and public opinion mean that there is growing need for industries and academia to work together towards greener and more sustainable practices. It is vital that we equip the next generation of scientists with the knowledge and skills to do so.</p>\r\n<p>From humble beginnings of a few research groups working in areas such as the replacement of commonly used hazardous reagents like AlCl&lt;sub&gt;3&lt;/sub&gt; in the 1980s, through the green chemistry movement started by the US EPA in the 1990s, there are now many green and sustainable chemistry initiatives worldwide. &nbsp;These range from large centres working in several areas, to educational programs and networks. Green chemistry is finding its way into various stages of education and in various countries: probably the most recognizable educational programs are the Masters courses now running in countries including the UK, France, Spain, Canada, Greece, India and Bulgaria. [bib]106[/bib] &nbsp;Green chemistry is probably less well developed at undergraduate levels, but in the US it has been estimated that 13 universities offer green chemistry courses with <a href=\"http://bcgc.berkeley.edu/education\">Berkeley being especially active including developing online activities</a>. &nbsp;A number of books and other resources offer green chemistry practicals mostly for undergraduate courses. [bib]107[/bib]&nbsp;</p>\r\n<p>Green chemistry centres are becoming widespread - these are mostly university-based with more than one senior academic based in the centre, and with a range of activities going beyond research, including for example education and networking. There are several in the USA (including<a href=\"http://bcgc.berkeley.edu/\"> UC Berkeley</a> and <a href=\"https://www.umb.edu/greenchemistry\">UMass Boston</a>) and others in Australia (<a href=\"http://www.chem.monash.edu/GreenChem\">Center for Green Chemistry at Monash</a>), Korea (including the <a href=\"http://english.krict.re.kr/eng/\">Korean Research Institute of Chemical Technology</a>), Mexico (<a href=\"http://www.fcq.uanl.mx/portal-fcc/plataforma-verde-quimica-verde/\">UANL</a>, Monterrey), India (<a href=\"http://greenchem.du.ac.in/\">University of Delhi</a>), Canada &nbsp;(<a href=\"https://www.greencentrecanada.com/\">Green Center Canada</a>) and the UK (<a href=\"www.york.ac.uk/chemistry/research/green/\">University of York</a>).</p>\r\n<p>The <a href=\"http://www.greenchemistrynetwork.org/\">Green Chemistry Network</a> (GCN) has recently launched a network of green and sustainable chemistry centres (<a href=\"http://g2c2.greenchemistrynetwork.org/\">G2C2</a>) in an attempt to improve communication between existing centres and to provide a guide for emerging centres in countries such as Brazil and South Africa. The first meeting of international centres took place in Delhi in December 2013. In addition, the <a href=\"http://www.acs.org/content/acs/en/greenchemistry.html\">Green Chemistry Institute</a> is highly active in promoting several important green chemistry initiatives such as <a You have scaled up the medicinal chemistry route, with a few modifications, to make multi Kg quantities of drug substance. Planning for phase III studies, a demand of 3 tonnes (3,000Kg) of API is requested. Do you stick with the current medicinal chemistry route and just scale-up, or do you invest time and resource in a new route? You need to justify your decision. </span></em></strong></p>\r\n<!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>\r\n <w:WordDocument>\r\n  <w:View>Normal</w:View>\r\n  <w:Zoom>0</w:Zoom>\r\n  <w:TrackMoves/>\r\n "repo.question", "pk": 102}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 2, "remote_id": 351, "dummy": false, "slug": "questions-to-consider", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<ul><li>Considering the An Ugi four component reaction is first applied to produce an acylated intermediate which is subsequently cyclised via a Pictet-Spengler reaction.&nbsp; This has been demonstrated on a small scale.&nbsp; With a reaction mass efficiency of 92.5, atom economy of 95.4 and mass intensity of 12.2 for the Ugi step (including work-up), and XX <a href=\"#_msocom_1\"></a>overall, this route shows promise as an efficient two-step synthesis of Praziquantel. &nbsp;Other advantages are that the by-products from the two steps are water and two equivalents of methanol and the reaction conditions are mild.</p><p>[figure:show:234]</p><p>Figure 1:&nbsp; 2 step route to Praziquantel devised by Cao et al.2</p>", "title": "API case study", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"type\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [35]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 105}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 0, "remote_id": 386, "dummy": false, "slug": "chem21-case-study", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>With important medicinal properties, isothioureas are an important class of compounds to the pharmaceutical industry; which have found use as anti-histamines, anti-bacterials, for treatment of peptic ulcers, HIV and influenza.[bib]http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ijantimicag.2011.08.015[/bib][bib]http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.bmcl.2013.09.052[/bib][bib]10.1021/jm201042n[/bib][bib]10.1021/jm801065q[/bib][bib]10.1002/ardp.201300276[/bib] They are also crucial intermediates in the synthesis of guanidines[bib]10.1039/C4CS00013G[/bib] (use in treatment of Lambert\u2011Eaton syndrome), with many routes to their synthesis reporting the formation of isothioureas as intermediates in their synthesis.[bib]10.1039/C4CS00013G[/bib] Beyond pharmaceutical applications isothioureas also have applications as agrochemicals as well as within the fine chemicals industry. &nbsp;<br /><br />Classically S-alkyl isothioureas are prepared from the corresponding thioureas by S-alkylation. The most common intermediates in the synthesis of guanidines, S-methylisothioureas are formed by reaction of methylisothioureas with the highly carcinogenic and neurotoxic methyl iodide (MeI).[bib]10.1002/anie.201406717[/bib] The use of alkyl halides to furnish S-alkyl isothioureas presents great a variety of disadvantages including the associated health risks, flammability and reactivity of the reagents.<br /><br />Given the industrial significance of isothioureas and relative lack of research into greener approaches to their synthesis, the CHEM21 researchers have developed a multicomponent reaction for the synthesis of isothioureas from isocyanides, thiosulfonates and amines,[bib]10.1002/anie.201406717[/bib] the classical approach requires three synthetic steps with associated chromatographic purification to achieve the alkylated isothiourea product, which the novel MCR approach can achieve in one step. It also circumvents the use of an alkyl halide for the S-alkylation (Scheme 1).<br /><br />[figure:236]<br /><br />The novel methodology allows access to a variety of novel isothioureas, including S-aryl isothioureas which are difficult to achieve by other methods.[bib]10.1002/anie.201406717[/bib] The method allows for the use of readily available isocyanides, thiosulfonates and (hetero)aromatics to achieve the target molecules in a single synthetic step. The methodology operates using a copper based catalyst, does not require air exclusion and operates under mild reaction temperatures.[bib]10.1002/anie.201406717[/bib]</p>", "title": "CHEM21 Case Study", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [35]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 106}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 1, "remote_id": 412, "dummy": false, "slug": "benefits-of-mcrs", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>The benefits of MCRs are that they bring together at least three reactants in one-pot bringing about an efficient and intrinsically atom economical reaction (generating a product that contains essentially all the atoms of the starting materials), generally under mild conditions and frequently using greener solvents.[bib]10.1039/C4GC00013G[/bib]</p><p>A major advantage of MCRs is <em>waste reduction</em> \u2013 due to their highly convergent nature, MCRs reduce waste generated by a process by incorporating a highly resource efficient step in the synthesis and often shortening the overall number of steps.&nbsp;&nbsp; Their excellent chemo-and regio-selectivity minimises the generation of side-products, and by products are typically simple, small molecules such as water, alcohols, amines or common salts, resulting in not only&nbsp; a reduced amount of waste, but the waste itself is generally benign (avoiding problems associated with the recovery and disposal of hazardous waste).&nbsp;</p><p>The work-up of these reactions is often straightforward via precipitation of the product, avoiding the use of more time consuming and resource intensive recovery and purification methods.&nbsp; Solvent use is also generally significantly reduced due to reaction telescoping and improved work-up.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp;</p>", "title": "Benefits of MCRs", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [41]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 107}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 3, "remote_id": 414, "dummy": false, "slug": "issues-with-mcrs", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>One issue with the MCRs is that a number of the MCR strategies use a cyanide or an isocyanide as one of the reaction components, the synthesis of which are typically themselves atom-inefficient and tend to use hazardous reagents and problematic solvents and as such the environmental implications of the preparation of these compounds must be taken into consideration (as well as the toxicity of the cyanide compounds). This reinforces the importance of looking upstream and downstream of a particular reaction step and thinking holistically to ensure that methodologies are genuinely greener.&nbsp;</p>\r\n<p>Research is underway to explore more environmentally acceptable methods of generating cyanides, for example the use of potassium hexacyanoferrate (II) as an environmentally benign cyanide source [bib]http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jorganchem.2012.02.005[/bib][bib]10.1055/s-0030-1258495[/bib].</p>", "title": "Issues with MCRs", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [41]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 108}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 2, "remote_id": 413, "dummy": false, "slug": "mcr-examples-and-metrics", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Table 1 demonstrates some representative examples of MCRs and some indicative green chemistry metrics.</p><p>[figure:show:235]</p>", "title": "MCR examples and metrics", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [41]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 109}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 1, "remote_id": 458, "dummy": false, "slug": "applications", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Organofluorine chemistry has a wide variety of applications, from the manufacture of pharmaceuticals and agrochemicals through to polymers and fuel cells.&nbsp; The presence of fluorine atom(s) in an API can provide beneficial effects through increased efficacy, due to for example improved metabolic stability; lipophilicity and/or improved bioavailability through changes to its pK<sub>a</sub>. (Ref Chem. Soc. Rev. 37 (2), 320-330 (2008)). &nbsp;In 2012, 35% of FDA approvals contained at least one C-F bond.<strong> (ref Vision 2020).</strong> Although fluorination remains a critical technology for the pharmaceutical industry, very little is done in house &ndash; at least in process and manufacturing. <strong>(ref Vision 2020)&nbsp;</strong></p>\r\n<p align=\"left\">Members of the CHEM21 project, Antal Harsanyi and Graham Sandford, based at Durham University published a perspective for the Green Chemistry Journal on &lsquo;Organofluorine chemistry: applications, sources and sustainability&rsquo; (<em>Green Chem</em>., 2015, <strong>17</strong>, 2081).&nbsp; You can read more about fluorine sources, applications and sustainability by reading the <a href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1039/C4GC02166E\">full paper</a>.</p>", "title": "Applications", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [42]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 110}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1274, 1275], "order": 3, "remote_id": 460, "dummy": false, "slug": "synthesis", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Organofluorine compounds are extremely rare in nature, and therefore the construction of carbon-fluorine bonds requires the use of synthetic fluorinating agents.&nbsp; The range of fluorinating agents used in chemical synthesis (see Figure 1) are ultimately all derived from the mineral fluorospar (CaF<sub>2</sub>) which is used to make anhydrous hydrogen fluoride (aHF), (see Figure 1).&nbsp;[bib]10.1039/C4GC02166E[/bib]&nbsp;</p>\r\n<p>[figure:show:244]</p>\r\n<p>Reproduced from with permission from:&nbsp;[ibib]10.1039/C4GC02166E[/ibib]</p>", "title": "Synthesis", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"type\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [42]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 111}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1276], "order": 2, "remote_id": 459, "dummy": false, "slug": "sustainability", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>There is a threat to the long term sustainability of organofluorine chemistry, as estimated reserves of fluorospar are set to last for approximately only another one hundred years.&nbsp; Therefore alternative sources of fluorine need to be explored.&nbsp;&nbsp; One route suggested in the paper&nbsp;[bib]10.1039/C4GC02166E[/bib] is the exploitation of a byproduct of the fertiliser industry &lsquo;fluorosilic acid&rsquo;, which is formed during the production of phosphoric acid from widely abundant phosphate rock.</p>", "title": "Sustainability", "dirty": "[]", "changed": false, "lessons": [42]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 112}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 0, "remote_id": 451, "dummy": false, "slug": "synthesis-of-organic-molecules", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Synthesis of organic molecules carrying a number of functionalities relies on the conversion of functional groups that display high reactivity, into the target functional groups. Carbon&ndash;hydrogen (C&ndash;H) bonds are not classically considered functional groups within the context of functionalisation. Therefore introduction of a new bond requires the presence of either a heteroatom on the carbon backbone, a leaving group or unsaturation.[bib]10.1126/science.1114731[/bib]</p>\r\n<p>In the pharmaceutical industry new C&ndash;C and C&ndash;X (X= C, N, O) bonds are typically made by cross coupling reactions shown in Scheme 1. Of the methods highlighted, the Heck and Suzuki reactions are the most popular forms of C&ndash;C bond formation in the pharmaceutical industry, however as can be seen from Scheme 1, both systems require pre-functionalisation of one of the coupling partners with a halogen, while the other requires the presence of a terminal alkane (Heck) or a boronic acid (Suzuki).[bib]10.1039/B602413K[/bib]&nbsp;Many synthetic intermediates do not lend themselves to the formation of terminal unsaturation, and boronic acids are synthesised from organometallic halides (e<ins cite=\"mailto:Louise%20Summerton\" datetime=\"2015-12-09T10:00\">.</ins>g<ins cite=\"mailto:Louise%20Summerton\" datetime=\"2015-12-09T10:00\">.</ins> Grignard reagents), which further adds to the complexity of what essentially is the formation of single bond. Aromatic and heteroaromatic groups are present in more than 75% of marketed pharmaceuticals, and their functionalisation represents a challenge to the synthetic community however, the recent developments in cross-coupling reactions catalysed by transition metals have enabled a range of methods for introducing aryl functionality, although their versatility is limited by the availability of aryl halides.[bib]10.1039/B703488C[/bib]</p>\r\n<p>[figure:show:246]</p>\r\n<p><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>\r\n <o:OfficeDocumentSettings>\r\n  <o:AllowPNG/>\r\n QFormat=\"true\" Name=\"TOC Heading\"/>\r\n </w:LatentStyles>\r\n</xml><![endif]--><!--[if !supportAnnotations]--><!--[endif]--><!--[if gte mso 10]>\r\n<style>\r\n /* Style Definitions */\r\n table.MsoNormalTable\r\n\t{mso-style-name:\"Table Normal\";\r\n\tmso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;\r\n\tmso-tstyle-colband-size:0;\r\n\tmso-style-noshow:yes;\r\n\tmso-style-priority:99;\r\n\tmso-style-parent:\"\";\r\n\tmso-padding-alt:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt;\r\n\tmso-para-margin-top:0cm;\r\n\tmso-para-margin-right:0cm;\r\n\tmso-para-margin-bottom:10.0pt;\r\n\tmso-para-margin-left:0cm;\r\n\tline-height:115%;\r\n\tmso-pagination:widow-orphan;\r\n\tfont-size:11.0pt;\r\n\tfont-family:\"Calibri\",\"sans-serif\";\r\n\tmso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;\r\n\tmso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;\r\n\tmso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;\r\n\tmso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;\r\n\tmso-fareast-language:EN-US;}\r\n</style>\r\n<![endif]--><strong><a name=\"_Ref436215037\"></a>Scheme 1 </strong><a style=\"mso-comment-reference: LS_1; mso-comment-date: 20151209T0959;\"><strong>Common C-C coupling reactions used in the pharmaceutical industry</strong> <br />(Reproduced directly with permission of the Royal Society of Chemistry from Fairlamb, <span style=\"background: yellow; mso-highlight: yellow;\">2016[bib]396[/bib]</span></a><span style=\"mso-comment-continuation: 1;\">)</span></p>\r\n<p>The approach for the synthesis of new bonds via pre-functionalisation dictates the process of synthetic strategy; reactive sites are typically incorporated by a series of transformations and as a result the starting materials can be very different to the final product. &nbsp;Thus, the direct conversion of C&ndash;H bonds of organic compounds into desired functional groups without pre-activation represents a crucial field in green synthetic chemistry.[bib]10.1073/pnas.0804348105[/bib]&nbsp;Such transformations have the potential to provide clean and economic methods for the preparation of a wide variety of important chemicals directly from hydrocarbons. Moreover, with such tools in the synthetic chemist&rsquo;s arsenal, new opportunities could present themselves that would have a significant impact on synthetic strategy.[bib]10.1073/pnas.0804348105[/bib]&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>\r\n<p>The challenge to direct C&ndash;H functionalisation stems from the high bond dissociation energy of the C&ndash;H bonds of aromatics and olefins (H&ndash;C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>5</sub>: 460 kJ/mol; H<sub>3</sub>C&ndash;H: 439 kJ/mol).&nbsp;[bib]10.1021/ar000209h[/bib]&nbsp;As such cleavage of these bonds requires high temperatures, the presence of strong oxidants and acidic or basic additives.[bib]10.1021/ar000209h[/bib]&nbsp;Such methods are incompatible for application with a significant number of functional groups, thus limiting their applicability. Accordingly, C&ndash;H bond functionalisation has been a subject of vigorous research over the last 20 years, and more recently with respect to the development of methods that overcome the drawbacks highlighted.[bib]10.1039/C1CS15083A[/bib]</p>\r\n<p>Recent reviews on the developments in C&ndash;H activation have been published by Glorius <em>et al</em>.&nbsp;[bib]10.1039/C1CS15083A[/bib]&nbsp;and Chang <em>et al</em>.&nbsp;[bib]10.1039/C1CS15082K[/bib]&nbsp;as well as a specialised review on organocatalytic C&ndash;H activation by Pan.[bib]10.3762/bjoc.8.159[/bib].</p>", "title": "Synthesis of organic molecules", "dirty": "[\"intro\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"type\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [43]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 113}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1253], "order": 1, "remote_id": 452, "dummy": false, "slug": "scarcity-of-metal-catalysts", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Catalysis is one of the overarching principles of green chemistry that offers significant energy, environmental and economic savings. At present, 85% of chemical products worldwide, both bulk and fine chemicals are made <em>via</em> methods that use a metal catalyst; most of these processes use precious metals to perform the chemical transformation. However, the limited abundance of these metals poses a substantial threat to these industries, even for those metals that are forecast to last for another 100 years (Figure 1) have various associated issues, such as the uncertain stability of their price based on the current rates of extraction. Furthermore, geopolitical uncertainty in areas that currently mine these metals, as well as potential market manipulation to limit the amount exported, can cause global shortages on the international markets.</p>\r\n<p>[figure:show:247]</p>", "title": "Scarcity of metal catalysts", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"type\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [44]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 114}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 3, "remote_id": 454, "dummy": false, "slug": "use-in-the-pharmaceutical-industry", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Within the pharmaceutical industry, precious metal based catalysts are predominantly used in cross\u2011coupling reactions, with 17% of the transformations catalysed by palladium [bib]10.1021/jm200187y[/bib] (please see <strong>introduction to C-H activation</strong>), other palladium catalysed transformations include hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis, Bn/CBz deprotection.</p>\r\n<p>Given the prevalence of the use of precious metals in the synthesis of important molecules, finding alternative methods is not clear cut; as there are associated issues with the required selectivity, and the use of a different method would require complete or partial redesign of large scale processes. Moreover, small changes in a production process for pharmaceutically relevant molecules would require reopening of the associated registration files, which would incur further costs. In addition to the issue of the scarcity and cost of precious metals, the ligands associated with them in a given method can be more expensive per mole than the metal itself, and there are no means for their recovery. [bib]375[/bib]</p>", "title": "Use in the pharmaceutical industry", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [44]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 115}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 3, "remote_id": 455, "dummy": false, "slug": "cost-and-scarcity-mitigation", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>The industry has gone some way to mitigating the cost and scarcity of catalytic species based on rare metals, through the development of metal reclaiming processes. An alternative strategy to metal reclaiming processes is to shift away from the use of scarce metals to more earth abundant and cheaper base metal catalysts. The major advantages to the use of base metal catalysts, aside from the greater abundance and low cost, include the fact that base metals exhibit low toxicity and are also environmentally benign.[bib]375[/bib]</p>\r\n<p>The application of such metals in catalysis has crawled behind the huge advances made by precious metals however; there has been a renewed interest in the challenge in matching or outperforming the high activity and selectivity demonstrated by the platinum group metals, through investigating new ligands and reaction conditions that overcome the unpredictable nature of base metals.&nbsp; First row transition metals are known to readily undergo one electron oxidation state changes, partake in uncontrolled reactions with elemental oxygen and display facile ligand redistribution. In contrast, precious metal catalysis has established a plethora of predictable chemistries based on two electron changes between oxidation states. Base metals such as cobalt, copper, nickel, iron among others are some of the most earth abundant and the nearly limitless supply of iron allows its use on vast reaction scales such as those of the Haber&ndash;Bosch ammonia synthesis.[bib]10.1021/acs.accounts.5b00385[/bib]</p>\r\n<p>Cobalt, iron and nickel catalysts have been investigated in parallel with palladium catalysts for carbon-carbon bond formation and it has been found that when supported by the appropriate ligands, nickel and cobalt can enable efficient coupling reactions allowing the formal addition of carbon-hydrogen bonds in unsaturated systems.&nbsp;[bib]10.1021/acs.accounts.5b00385[/bib] Iminopyridine ligands have shown promise as privileged ligands in iron catalysis, and have been used in iron-catalysed methodologies for the production of olefin hydrogenation, carbon&ndash;carbon and carbon&ndash;hetroatom bond formation.</p>\r\n<p>There have been many recent developments in the use of base metal catalysis in the synthesis of pharmaceutically relevant intermediates, many of which can be found in the <em>Accounts of Chemical Research</em> special issue &ldquo;Earth Abundant Metals in Homogeneous Catalysis&rdquo;.</p>", "title": "Cost and scarcity mitigation", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [44]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 116}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1277], "order": 4, "remote_id": 461, "dummy": false, "slug": "fluorinating-agents", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Fluorinating agents are, by their inherent highly reactive nature, not generally regarded as green or sustainable due to associated hazards and toxicity issues.&nbsp; However modern alternatives are being developed alongside safer handling techniques that facilitate safer halogenation reactions, with minimal impact on the environment <strong>(ref Chapter 17 of ebook)</strong></p>\r\n<p>The table below provides a summary of the main advantages and disadvantages of various fluorinating agents.<strong> (ref Chapter 17 of ebook)</strong></p>\r\n<p><strong>&nbsp;</strong></p>\r\n<table border=\"1\" cellspacing=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\">\r\n<tbody>\r\n<tr>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"154\">\r\n<p><strong>Fluorinating Agent</strong></p>\r\n</td>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"154\">\r\n<p><strong>What is it used to fluorinate</strong></p>\r\n</td>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"154\">\r\n<p><strong>Why is it green?</strong></p>\r\n<p><strong>Advantages</strong></p>\r\n</td>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"154\">\r\n<p><strong>Why is it not green?</strong></p>\r\n<p><strong>Disadvantages</strong></p>\r\n</td>\r\n</tr>\r\n<tr>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"154\">\r\n<p>Elemental Fluorine</p>\r\n</td>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"154\">\r\n<p>Carbonyl compounds</p>\r\n<p>Aromatics</p>\r\n<p>C-H bonds</p>\r\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\r\n</td>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"154\">\r\n<p>Excellent atom economy</p>\r\n</td>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"154\">\r\n<p>Highly reactive, toxic</p>\r\n<p>Specialist handling needed</p>\r\n<p>Often generate HF byproducts</p>\r\n</td>\r\n</tr>\r\n<tr>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"154\">\r\n<p>HF</p>\r\n</td>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"154\">\r\n<p>Halide Displacements (S<sub>N</sub>2)</p>\r\n</td>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"154\">\r\n<p>Excellent atom economy</p>\r\n</td>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"154\">\r\n<p>Extremely corrosive and hazardous</p>\r\n</td>\r\n</tr>\r\n<tr>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"154\">\r\n<p>Fluoride Salts (e.g. KF, CsF)</p>\r\n</td>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"154\">\r\n<p>Halide Displacements (S<sub>N</sub>2)</p>\r\n</td>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"154\">\r\n<p>Safe and easy to handle</p>\r\n<p>Excellent
