"lessons": [42]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 117}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 6, "remote_id": 462, "dummy": false, "slug": "further-reading", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>On green and sustainable halogenation processes: <br />G. Pattison in [ibib]374[/ibib]</p>", "title": "Further reading", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [42]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 118}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1263], "order": 1, "remote_id": 472, "dummy": false, "slug": "prevalence-of-the-amide-bond", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>The amide bond is a ubiquitous functionality; occurring in natural products, polymers and pharmaceutical molecules. In publications by Carey <em>et al.[bib]10.1039/B602413K[/bib]</em> and Roughley <em>et al.[bib]10.1021/jm200187y[/bib]</em> investigating the most commonly used chemical transformations in industrial Research and Development (R&amp;D) departments (process and medicinal chemistry) at three large pharmaceutical companies, both included amide bond formation as one of the top ten transformations in these fields. It is therefore unsurprising that amide bonds feature in more than 25% of known pharmaceutical molecules. The top selling drug in 2008 atorvastatin (trade name Lipitor&reg;) with sales of $12.4 billion contains a single amide bond. Other important drug molecules that carry an amide bond include penicillin (antibiotic), paracetamol (analgesic) and chloramphenicol (broad-spectrum antibiotic), Figure 1.&nbsp;</p>\r\n<p>[figure:show:250]</p>", "title": "Prevalence of the amide bond", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"type\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [45]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 119}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1264, 1265], "order": 2, "remote_id": 473, "dummy": false, "slug": "condensation", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Amide bond formation between an acid and an amine are formally condensations. The related esterification reactions are governed by equilibrium however, the mixing of an amine with a carboxylic acid or an acid base reaction forms a stable salt. This means that amide bond formation between these reactants is thermodynamically disfavoured as the equilibrium lies on the side of hydrolysis rather than bond formation, Scheme 1.</p>\r\n<p>[figure:show:251]</p>\r\n<p><strong>Scheme 1: Amide bond formation by reaction of an amine with a carboxylic acid is thermodynamically disfavoured</strong></p>\r\n<p>The subsequent condensation of the salt to give the amide bond can be achieved at high reaction temperatures ~160-180 &deg;C, which is not only energy demanding but can be incompatible in the presence of other functionalities. These forcing reaction conditions have been circumvented by activating the carboxylic acid by using a good leaving group bound to the acyl group of the acid, allowing the necessary attack by the amine group, Scheme 2.</p>\r\n<p>[figure:show:252]</p>\r\n<p><strong>Scheme 2: Amide bond formation through activating of the acyl carbon</strong></p>\r\n<p></p>", "title": "Condensation", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"type\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [45]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 120}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 3, "remote_id": 474, "dummy": false, "slug": "synthetic-methods", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Given the importance of amide bonds there is a plethora of synthetic methods and strategies available for their synthesis. The most popular industrial methods for amide bond formation rely on the aforementioned acylation method which account for 16% of all reactions carried out by the pharmaceutical industry, a breakdown of these methods is shown in Table 1.[bib]10.1039/B602413K[/bib]</p>\r\n<p>Table 1: Breakdown of acylation methods for amide bond formation in the pharmaceutical industry[bib]10.1039/B602413K[/bib]</p>\r\n<div align=\"center\">\r\n<table border=\"1\" cellspacing=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\">\r\n<tbody>\r\n<tr>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"205\">\r\n<p align=\"center\"><strong>Method</strong></p>\r\n</td>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"205\">\r\n<p align=\"center\"><strong>Frequency (%)</strong></p>\r\n</td>\r\n</tr>\r\n<tr>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"205\">\r\n<p align=\"center\"><strong>Acid Chloride</strong></p>\r\n</td>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"205\">\r\n<p align=\"center\">52</p>\r\n</td>\r\n</tr>\r\n<tr>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"205\">\r\n<p align=\"center\"><strong>Coupling reagent</strong></p>\r\n</td>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"205\">\r\n<p align=\"center\">21</p>\r\n</td>\r\n</tr>\r\n<tr>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"205\">\r\n<p align=\"center\"><strong>Mixed carbonic anhydrides</strong></p>\r\n</td>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"205\">\r\n<p align=\"center\">11</p>\r\n</td>\r\n</tr>\r\n<tr>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"205\">\r\n<p align=\"center\"><strong>Carbonyl Diimidazole</strong></p>\r\n</td>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"205\">\r\n<p align=\"center\">9</p>\r\n</td>\r\n</tr>\r\n<tr>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"205\">\r\n<p align=\"center\"><strong>Other</strong></p>\r\n</td>\r\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"205\">\r\n<p align=\"center\">6</p>\r\n</td>\r\n</tr>\r\n</tbody>\r\n</table>\r\n</div>\r\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\r\n<p>The use of acid chlorides is the most common method for amide bond formation in industry, and in the majority of cases, the procedure involves <em>in situ</em> generation of the acid chloride. Mixed carbonic anhydrides provide a cheap and readily scaled method for <em>N</em>-acylation.[bib]10.1039/B602413K[/bib] In recent years the use of carbonyl diimidazole (CDI) has grown in popularity, as it is moderately priced and also readily scaled and worked up, however its use is limited as CDI is a sensitiser and its use on large scale is costly.[bib]10.1039/B602413K[/bib]&nbsp; The use of acyl chlorides and mixed anhydrides is an economical approach to the synthesis of amides, however all of these acylation methods use stoichiometric quantities of coupling agents, which make them expensive, wasteful and inefficient.</p>\r\n<p>Amide bond formation using enzymatic catalysis circumvents the poor atom economy associated with coupling agents, as well as the potential hazards related with the use of non-aqueous media chemical approaches.&nbsp; Methods such as lipase-catalysed amidation of carboxylic acids and the hydrolysis of nitriles catalysed by nitrile hydrolases are clean, efficient and safe routes to the synthesis of primary amides. Equally, the use of peptidases and acylases circumvents the need for protection/deprotection steps, which has a positive impact on the mass intensity of the process.&nbsp; The use of enzyme catalysed amide bond formation has the advantage of operating under mild reaction conditions and their specificity leads to excellent regio- and stereoselectivity.&nbsp;&nbsp; Despite the progress made in the area of biocatalytic amide bond formation and some commercial success, enzyme catalysed amide synthesis still suffers from a narrow substrate specificity and material intensive isolation stages, which limit their application.[bib]10.1039/B703488C[/bib]</p>\r\n<p>In their survey of the reactions used by the pharmaceutical industry in the production of drug candidates, Carey <em>et al.</em><em><sup>1</sup></em> note that not a single catalytic method was used for the synthesis of amides.&nbsp; There is still a pressing need for scalable catalytic methodologies for the synthesis of amides that are atom efficient and avoid the production of waste; this has encouraged research into the efficient preparation of amide bonds. Details on recent developments in the synthesis of amide bonds can be found in reviews by Valeur and Bradley[bib]10.1039/B701677H[/bib], Montalbetti <em>et al</em>.[bib]http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.tet.2005.08.031[/bib] and Pattabiraman and Bode.[bib]470[/bib] A specialised review of metal\u2011catalysed approaches to amide bond formation was published by Allen and Williams[bib]10.1039/C0CS00196A[/bib], and a recent review on catalytic amide bond formation on non-activated amines and carboxylic acids has been published by Adolfsson and co-wrokers.[bib]10.1039/C3CS60345H[/bib]</p>", "title": "Synthetic methods", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [45]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 121}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 5, "remote_id": 476, "dummy": false, "slug": "recommended-reading", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p><strong>Recommended reading:</strong></p>\r\n<p>Farhana K. Ferdousi &amp; Andrew Whiting in [ibib]374[/ibib]</p>", "title": "Recommended reading", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [45]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 122}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 1, "remote_id": 487, "dummy": false, "slug": "flask-vs-pipe-vs-cstr", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>The flask is an integral piece of equipment to the synthetic organic or medicinal chemist at lab scale however, on large scale the flask is uneconomical. The bulk chemical, petrochemical and polymer industries all opt for the use of pipes as the reaction vessels of choice, allowing them continuous operation and enhanced control over reaction conditions. The pharmaceutical and fine chemical industries on the other hand, frequently use continuous stirred tank reactors (CSTRs) to perform their reactions.&nbsp; The reason for the disparity of approach between these industries is that in the pharmaceutical industry, process development occurs incrementally over a number of years beginning with milligram scale and increasing successively by several orders of magnitude up to a scale of tons, as required.[bib]10.1039/C3GC40374B[/bib]&nbsp; As such scale up in the pharmaceutical industry is carried out by gradual increase in the size of the reactor rather than performing a costly and time-inefficient redesign of a process.[bib]10.1039/C3GC40374B[/bib]</p>", "title": "Flask vs. Pipe vs. CSTR", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [46]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 123}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 2, "remote_id": 488, "dummy": false, "slug": "benefits-of-flow-chemistry", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>The aims of green chemistry and industry support one another when a process is considered for upscaling; it needs to be safe, generate minimal waste and be energy efficient. A fundamental approach to green chemistry for industrial application is to address such issues at the outset of the project, ideally at the reaction discovery stage. Flow chemistry is an enabling technology that fits well at the interface between reaction discovery and scale up; such reactors offer substantial improvements in the management of heat and mixing as well as scalability, energy efficiency, waste generation, operational safety, offer a wide range of reaction conditions and unique opportunities for catalyst supports, telescoping reactions among others.[bib]10.1039/C1GC16022B[/bib][bib]10.1002/tcr.201100041[/bib][bib]10.1002/cssc.201000271[/bib]</p>\r\n<p>The advantages in efficiency and sustainability that continuous flow offers are that it allows for efficient use of energy and time. Both aspects being directly related to reaction rate as a slow reaction would require more time for completion. The standard approach for speeding up a reaction is to increase its temperature, however batch reactors are limited to the boiling point of the reaction solvent/reagents, by comparison flow reactors lend themselves well to safe temperature and pressure manipulation beyond that of standard atmospheric conditions. Thus reactions carried out in flow are often faster than the corresponding batch reactions and offer improved energy, time and even space efficiency, as faster reactions will require smaller reactors.[bib]10.1039/C3GC40374B[/bib] Many green solvents such as acetone or methanol have low boiling points making them inapplicable for use in certain reactions; performing reactions at high pressure in a flow reactor allows for their safe use at high temperatures.[bib]10.1039/C3GC40374B[/bib]&nbsp; Supercritical fluids add an extra facet, as they are inaccessible in the absence of high temperature conditions, thus their applicability in flow reactors offers further advantages over batch reactors.[bib]10.1039/C3GC40374B[/bib]</p>", "title": "Benefits of flow chemistry", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [46]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 124}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 3, "remote_id": 489, "dummy": false, "slug": "catalysis", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Catalysis is an important aspect of green chemistry and there have been many efforts to develop supported catalysts for use on large scale. In small scale batch reactions, the catalyst, reagents, reactants and solvent are mixed together and stirred until reaction completion, after which the bulk liquid is separated by filtration, after which the catalyst is collected for re-use or disposal.[bib]10.1039/C3GC40374B[/bib] In continuous systems, the catalyst can be fixed in space over which the reaction mixture is allowed to flow, allowing the reaction and the separation steps to be combined into a single stage.[bib]10.1039/C3GC40374B[/bib] The catalyst remains in the reactor, allowing for ease of recycling; this system also allows the catalyst a longer lifetime as a result of the reduced exposure to the external environment.[bib]10.1039/C0GC00133C[/bib] As a result, reaction rates and catalyst turnover numbers are augmented through use of high catalyst concentrations and continuous recycling. &nbsp;</p>\r\n<p>An area of chemistry that has been difficult to implement on large scale pharmaceutical production is photochemistry; light has long been considered a valuable tool for performing synthetic reactions, it acts as a traceless agent facilitating the reaction without the production of further waste or the need for removal from the reaction mixture.[bib]10.1039/C3GC40374B[/bib][bib]10.1002/anie.201200223[/bib][bib]10.1039/B913880N[/bib]Though photochemistry has found application on industrial scale, its use is still uncommon in the pharmaceutical and fine chemicals industry; largely due to the use of batch reactors and the challenges associated with using photochemistry on a large scale, where the sheer volume of the reactor does not allow for complete light penetration.[bib]10.3762/bjoc.8.229[/bib][bib]10.1002/ceat.201200009[/bib] Flow chemistry allows better access to photochemistry as a tool at a range of scales using inexpensive equipment: &nbsp;the reaction mixture is pumped through a transparent tubing or transparent chip microreactor which is irradiated with a light source, the small diameter of the tubes allows for satisfactory light penetration, permitting all reaction molecules to be exposed to the same amount of heat and light. This comprehensive light exposure generally means that photochemical reactions run in flow tend to be orders of magnitude faster than their corresponding batch reactors.[bib]10.1039/C3GC40374B[/bib]</p>", "title": "Catalysis", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [46]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 125}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 4, "remote_id": 490, "dummy": false, "slug": "challenges", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>One of the major challenges to the efficiency and sustainability of fine chemical and pharmaceutical industrial scale production is that the final product usually involves a multiple step synthesis with numerous work-up and purification steps required at each stage, which impact negatively on the material efficiency of the industry. Thus, approaches that circumvent or simplify these steps can have an enormous environmental impact on multi-step chemical syntheses; even here continuous flow reactors offer a great advantage as they are well suited for telescoping reactions and many methods have been developed to enable this.[bib]10.1039/C3GC40374B[/bib][bib]10.1039/C0SC00381F[/bib]&nbsp;</p>\r\n<p>Reaction scale-up usually requires costly re-optimisation reactions due to the change in mixing and heating properties, thus reactions that may have worked well on bench-scale batch reactions may require increased times, super-cooling, or may be impossible to carry out on large scale. Good reactions should be easily scaled without requiring re-optimisation, since a green reaction should be scalable by default.&nbsp; Again flow methods offer an advantage: the basic way to modify the total amount of product prepared in a continuous system is to change the length of time the reaction is run. <em>Ergo</em>, continuous flow processes allow facile alteration of the amount of product output without the need to modify the whole process or by running multiple batches, therefore meeting the green chemical engineering principle of running to meet needs.[bib]10.1039/C3GC40374B[/bib]</p>", "title": "Challenges", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [46]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 126}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 6, "remote_id": 491, "dummy": false, "slug": "summary", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>In summary, flow chemistry offers a viable and in certain cases superior alternative to batch processes; offering increased safety, efficiency and scalability. The application of continuous flow methods on process scale has seen rapid take up in recent years, and the research communities have been developing these approaches further to expand their scope of application. &nbsp;Recent reviews on the developments in flow chemistry and more detailed information on their advantages over batch reactors can be found in reviews by Newman and Jensen[bib]10.1039/C3GC40374B[/bib], Wiles and Watts[bib]10.1039/C1GC16022B[/bib] and&nbsp; Ley[bib]10.1002/tcr.201100041[/bib].</p>", "title": "Summary", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [46]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 127}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 2, "remote_id": 521, "dummy": false, "slug": "benefits-of-biosynthetic-approaches", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>The biggest challenges to the production of fine chemicals on large scale include environmental pollution, toxic waste, and the increasing cost of prevention and clean-up of environmental waste. Compared with chemical synthesis, biosynthetic approaches can offer several advantages; enzymes generally operate under biologically relevant conditions such as ambient temperatures and pressures, aqueous media and neutral pHs. This enables an array of diverse enzymes to work concurrently in the same environment e.g. a cell, as such it becomes possible to assemble a multistep synthetic pathway for the <em>in vivo</em> production of a complex molecule from cheap and abundant materials. This is in great contrast to traditional chemical multistep syntheses which would require purification, recovery and further processing of intermediates <em>en route</em> to the final product.&nbsp;[bib]10.1038/embor.2013.178[/bib]</p>\r\n<p>These characteristics of biotransformation facilitate &ldquo;one-pot synthesis&rdquo;, which is a challenging approach in chemotransfomations. The use of biosynthesis would thus circumvent the need for energy intensive and harsh reaction conditions, toxic or caustic chemicals and would enable the reactions to be carried out in greener solvents.[bib]10.1038/embor.2013.178[/bib] Bioderived chemicals would also limit the greenhouse gas emissions and the cost through use of cheaper simpler starting materials such as CO<sub>2</sub>,CO, hydrogen and salts.[bib]496[/bib]</p>\r\n<p>Although the repertoire of products made by naturally occurring organisms is broad, it is still predefined by evolution as the organisms have adapted their biochemistries for survival in particular environments. Synthetic biology can be used to modify the biochemistries of these organisms and tailor their metabolic pathways towards the production of pharmaceutically relevant products or intermediates from simple molecules.[bib]10.1002/anie.201302195[/bib]</p>", "title": "Benefits of biosynthetic approaches", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_resources\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [48]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 128}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1272], "order": 1, "remote_id": 522, "dummy": false, "slug": "fundamental-concepts", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Synthetic biology has been subject to numerous definitions, however all of the available ones agree that synthetic biology is the study of applying the principles of engineering to biology for productive purposes: the use of synthetic biology tools to deliberately design and construct biological systems or their parts to serve a particular purpose. A key area in synthetic biology is the construction of living &ldquo;production plants&rdquo; for the manufacture of complex chemical compounds from simpler starting materials, other research areas include bioinformatics (using synthetic gene networks), synthetic genomics and genome minimisation as well as the biosafety and societal aspects of synthetic biology among others.&nbsp;[bib]496[/bib]</p>\r\n<p>In synthetic biology, &ldquo;chassis&rdquo; cells &ndash;cells within which the desired metabolic pathways can be expressed&ndash; are considered living cells that possess a basic metabolic pathway to produce primary metabolites and are capable of essential chemical transformations such as the production of energy and co-factor regeneration. The chassis can thus be furnished with a desired function such as the ability to produce a chosen chemical compound; whether the compound is natural or non-natural does not hold a bearing on the process as long as the genetic information for driving its synthesis is available or can be designed. The chassis is endowed with the appropriate genetic system that consists of devices (e.g. different DNA vectors), made of different parts (e.g. promoters, terminators, ribosome binding sites), Figure 1.[bib]496[/bib]</p>\r\n<p>[figure:show:256]</p>\r\n<p><strong>Figure 1</strong> Parts, devices and systems - the make of a chassis cell (reproduced directly from Glieder, 2016[bib]496[/bib] with permission from the Royal Society of Chemistry)</p>\r\n<p>The concept of a chassis cell and its genetic system given in Figure 1 is an overly simplified representation; even in the simplest unicellular life form, genetic and metabolic processes do not work independently but have complex interactions in the cellular environment. However, the modular approach for the systematic assembly of a more complex genetic system from the well-defined essential parts is useful and essential for a systematic approach, as such powerful strategies that link the constituent parts together in an ordered, parallel or combinatorial manner have been developed.[bib]10.1002/anie.201302195[/bib]</p>", "title": "Fundamental concepts", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"type\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [48]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 129}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 3, "remote_id": 523, "dummy": false, "slug": "applications", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>This approach has already found its way into industrial scale production of a variety of important molecules such as the production of insulin from <em>E. coli </em>and more recently in the production of naturally occurring bio-products such as the plastic monomers succinic acid and lactic acid, and <em>n</em>-butanol as a solvent and next generation biofuel.[bib]496[/bib] This area is still in its nascence, but as it begins to mature it has the potential to carry significant impact on the green credentials of the pharmaceutical and fine chemical industry. A review on recent developments in the field of synthetic biology in the pharmaceutical industry has &nbsp;been published by Breitling and Takano.[bib]http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.copbio.2015.02.004[/bib]</p>", "title": "Applications", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_resources\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [48]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 130}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1273], "order": 1, "remote_id": 525, "dummy": false, "slug": "formal-stereoselective-c-h-amination", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p><strong>[TODO: references]</strong></p>\r\n<p>Stereoselective C-H amination is a very attractive strategy for the conversion of simple low cost chemical starting materials to high value chiral amine building blocks, and has therefore attracted much interest in organic chemistry. &alpha;-Methylbenzylamine is a substructure of many complex organic molecules. <sup>[1]</sup> Therefore, it can be a valuable intermediate in their synthesis.</p>\r\n<p>The most successful chemical strategies reported so far have involved intramolecular and transition-metal catalysed reactions<sup>[2]</sup> with a number of elegant methods using both chemical<sup>[3]</sup> and enzymatic<sup>[4]</sup> catalysts. A cascade of 2 enzymes was reported recently for the terminal amination of fatty acid methyl esters<sup>[5]</sup> employing a recombinant biosynthetic cascade in a whole cell system. Previous work had already shown that whole-cell biotransformation is able to produce chiral amine from secondary alcohol, albeit in low conversion of 3%.<sup>[6]</sup></p>\r\n<p>Given that natural biosynthetic cascades often suffer from limited substrate ranges, we were interested to generate a <em>de novo</em> biosynthetic multienzyme cascade that is guided in design and build by retrosynthetic considerations.<sup>[7]</sup> The target enzymes for the cascade were carefully chosen to be complementary in substrate recognition. By introducing the pathway into <em>Escherichia coli</em> we have generated a biocatalyst which converts ethylbenzenes <strong>1a-e</strong> to predominantly (R)-1-phenylethanamines <strong>4a-e</strong> respectively (figure 1) with conversions of up to 26% and ee values of 97.5%. Under the present reaction conditions, no additional co-factor except for the amine donor IPA and molecular oxygen was required. Our approach is the first fully enzymatic approach to generate chiral amines at the benzylic position from alkyls.</p>\r\n<p>[figure:show:258]</p>\r\n<p class=\"SchemeCaption\"><strong>Figure 1 </strong><strong>|</strong><em>E.coli</em> BL21(DE3) cells harbouring a self-sufficient P450 monooxygenase (Y96F)<sup>[8]</sup> which produces scalemic mixtures of alcohols with a general preference for the (<em>R</em>)-enantiomer,<sup>[9]</sup> (<em>R</em>)- and (<em>S</em>)-selective alcohol dehydrogenases (<em>Lb</em>RADH using NADP<sup>+</sup><sup>[10]</sup> and <em>Re</em>SADH using NAD<sup>+</sup> as co-factor<sup>[11]</sup>), and an w-transaminase (ATA117 requiring an amine donor and pyridoxal 5&rsquo;-phosphate (PLP)<sup>[12]</sup>) capable to convert 4-substituted ethylbenzenes <strong>1a-e </strong>into alcohols&nbsp; <strong>2a-e, </strong>ketones<strong> 3a-e </strong>andfinally amines<strong> 4a-e.</strong></p>\r\n<p class=\"P1withIndendation\">The flexible generic nature of the design of the cascade will allow for the easy substitution of individual enzymes with homologues or mutants and thereby provide a cassette based modular approach for the design and construction of alternative cascades for the enantioselective C-H amination of other substrates.</p>\r\n<p class=\"P1withIndendation\">&nbsp;</p>", "title": "Formal stereoselective C-H amination", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"type\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [40]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 131}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1271], "order": 2, "remote_id": 526, "dummy": false, "slug": "reductive-amination", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Chiral amines are an important class of organic compounds that serve as key intermediates in the synthesis of a variety of biologically active molecules.[bib]10.1007/s11244-013-0184-1[/bib] The formation of C=N bonds by the condensation of carbonyls and amines, followed by reduction of the <em>in situ</em> formed imine represents the most straightforward strategy for the generation of chiral amines.</p>\r\n<p>Most work has focused on the transition metal-catalyzed asymmetric hydrogenation of imines and particular attention was paid to the reductive amination of carbonyl compounds with primary amines. Several reagents and combinations have been reported through the years with a predominant role being played by modified borohydride reagents.[bib]10.1002/adsc.200900719[/bib] Inspired by the biological system NAD(P)H, Hantzsch ester has been employed as a hydrogen donor in combination with chiral phosphoric acid for the enantioselective reductive amination of aliphatic ketones to furnish amines with excellent enantioselectivities.[bib]10.1002/anie.201001715[/bib][bib]516[/bib][bib]10.1002/anie.200503062[/bib]</p>\r\n<p>The application of biocatalysis is an important complement to chemical catalysis for chiral amine synthesis in water. Two main types of enzymes were investigated so far for the transformation of carbonyl groups into amines: amino acid dehydrogenases and w-transaminases. Researchers within CHEM21 have identified imine reductases[bib]10.1002/cbic.201402213[/bib] as biocatalyst for chemo- and stereoselective intermolecular reductive aminations. This novel imine reductase-catalyzed approach constitutes a direct method for the synthesis of valuable amines under mild reaction conditions.[bib]10.1002/cctc.201500764[/bib]</p>\r\n<p>[figure:show:260]</p>\r\n<p><strong>Scheme 1: Classical and novel reductive amination</strong></p>\r\n<p>This approach represents a simple and complementary strategy for the generation of novel carbon nitrogen bonds in aqueous reaction media. These reactions proceed efficiently for a variety of carbonyl compounds and amine nucleophiles. Low amounts of the imine intermediate led to the formation of valuable amines in good yields and high selectivities. A highly chemo- and stereoselective imine reductase was applied in reductive aminations of a panel of carbonyls and amine nucleophiles to afford primary and secondary amine products in moderate to high yield as well as enantiomeric excess.[bib]10.1002/cctc.201500764[/bib]</p>", "title": "Reductive amination", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"type\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "model": "repo.question", "pk": 134}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 2, "remote_id": 545, "dummy": false, "slug": "issues-on-a-small-scale", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Within medicinal chemistry, the need to synthesise small amounts of a large number of analogues in a short time period can often lead to preference for tried and tested methodologies.&nbsp; This can be to the detriment of efficiency and often using reagents that would not be suitable for use on a larger scale due to, for example, safety issues.&nbsp; However green chemistry and medicinal chemistry are not mutually exclusive and adoption of green methodologies at an early stage in drug design provides the opportunity not only to reduce the environmental impact of small scale discovery research, but also to facilitate a smoother transition when promising candidates are scaled-up.</p>", "title": "Issues on a small scale", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_resources\", \"h5p_library\"]", "introduction-to-the-select-criteria", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>The biggest impact a chemist can have on the economic and environmental performance of a manufacturing process is in selecting the optimum synthetic route using the best available techniques/technologies at that moment in time.&nbsp; Route selection is a complex process, and synthetic routes can change during the development pipeline of an API, and post launch as part of life cycle management activity.&nbsp; 'Critical Assessment of Pharmaceutical Processes; A Rationale for Changing the Synthetic Route'&nbsp;[bib]10.1021/cr050982w[/bib] developed the widely adopted SELECT criteria.&nbsp; A manufacturing route could be improved/ changed to meet any or all of the SELECT criteria.&nbsp; </p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>S &ndash; Safety &ndash; removal/minimization of hazardous reagents/solvents.</li>\r\n<li>E &ndash; Environmental &ndash; removal/minimization of reagents/solvents harmful to the environment.</li>\r\n<li>L &ndash; Legal &ndash; no infringement of existing intellectual property.</li>\r\n<li>E &ndash; Economics &ndash; minimise cost of goods.</li>\r\n<li>C &ndash; Control Prat, J. Hayler, A. Wells,<em> Green Chem.</em>, 2014, <strong>16</strong>, 4546.) and<cite> </cite>D. Prat, O. Pardigon, H.-W. Flemming, S. Letestu, V. Ducandas, P. Isnard, et al.,<em> Org. Process Res. Dev.</em>, 2013, <strong>17</strong>, 1517.)</p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>Chemical efficiency for the reaction (<em>as well as downstream considerations of isolation/work-up etc.</em>)</li>\r\n<li>Safety/stability (<em>flammability, flash point, resistivity, energy of decomposition, risk of peroxides</em>)</li>\r\n<li>Human health issues (<em>acute, long-term and single target organ toxicity</em>)</li>\r\n<li>Environment (<em>biodegradability, ecotoxicity, solubility in water, volatility, odour, life cycle analysis</em>)</li>\r\n<li>Quality (<em>in the case of pharmaceuticals this is related to the risk of impurities in the drug substance</em>)</li>\r\n<li>Industrial Constraints (<em>such as boiling point, freezing temperature, density, recoverability/recyclability</em>)</li>\r\n<li>Cost</li>\r\n<li>Compliance with legislation (<em>e.g. regulations such as REACh is impacting on the use of some hazardous solvents, for example dipolar aprotics</em>)</li>\r\n</ul>", "title": "What factors are taken into consideration when selecting a solvent? ", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [51]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 141}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 0, "remote_id": null, "dummy": false, "slug": "survey-of-solvent-use", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>The CHEM21 project conducted a survey of solvent usage for papers published in Organic Process Research &amp; Development over a 6 year period (from 1997&ndash;2012) looking at three particular solvent classes:</p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>solvents of concern (dichloromethane, n-hexane, diisopropyl ether, 1,2- dimethoxyethane, 1,4-dioxane, diethyl ether, 1,2-dichloroethane, and chloroform)</li>\r\n<li>dipolar aprotic solvents</li>\r\n<li>neoteric solvents.</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;(Ref D. Prat, J. Hayler, A. Wells,<em> Green Chem.</em>, 2014, <strong>16</strong>, 4546)</p>\r\n<p>Key findings were that:</p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>Approximately half of the instances for use of dipolar aprotic solvents were for nucleophilic substitution reactions (primarily SNAr and SN2 reactions).&nbsp; The paper makes suggestions of how the use of DMF/DMAc/NMP/DMSO in these reactions could be reduced.</li>\r\n<li>2-methyltetrahydrofuran was the only neoteric solvent that demonstrated a significant increase in its during the survey period.</li>\r\n<li>Although some solvents of concern are unfortunately still being employed, pleasingly on on greater than 100Kg scale the survey showed that there is a large reduction in the use of DMF, n-hexane, diisopropylether, DMAc, DMSO and &lsquo;the complete elimination of diethyl ether and dioxane&rsquo;</li>\r\n</ul>", "title": "Survey of solvent use", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"json_content\", \"id\", \"h5p_library\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": []}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 142}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 4, "remote_id": 554, "dummy": false, "slug": "survey-of-solvent-use", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>The CHEM21 project conducted a survey of solvent usage for papers published in Organic Process Research &amp; Development over a 6 year period (from 1997&ndash;2012) looking at three particular solvent classes:</p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>solvents of concern (dichloromethane, n-hexane, diisopropyl ether, 1,2- dimethoxyethane, 1,4-dioxane, diethyl ether, 1,2-dichloroethane, and chloroform)</li>\r\n<li>dipolar aprotic solvents</li>\r\n<li>neoteric solvents.</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;(Ref D. Prat, J. Hayler, A. Wells,<em> Green Chem.</em>, 2014, <strong>16</strong>, 4546)</p>\r\n<p>Key findings were that:</p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>Approximately half of the instances for use of dipolar aprotic solvents were for nucleophilic substitution reactions (primarily SNAr and SN2 reactions).&nbsp; The paper makes suggestions of how the use of DMF/DMAc/NMP/DMSO in these reactions could be reduced.</li>\r\n<li>2-methyltetrahydrofuran was the only neoteric solvent that demonstrated a significant increase in its during the survey period.</li>\r\n<li>Although some solvents of concern are unfortunately still being employed, pleasingly on on greater than 100Kg scale the survey showed that there is a large reduction in the use of DMF, n-hexane, diisopropylether, DMAc, DMSO and &lsquo;the complete elimination of diethyl ether and dioxane&rsquo;</li>\r\n</ul>", "title": "Survey of solvent use", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [51]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 143}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 1, "remote_id": 556, "dummy": false, "slug": "legislative-drivers", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<ul><li>Industrial Emissions Directive</li><li>Water Framework Directive (WFD) (<a href=\"http://ec.europa.eu/environment/water/water-framework/index_en.html\">http://ec.europa.eu/environment/water/water-framework/index_en.html</a>)</li></ul><p>The WFD seeks to <b>constantly improve the quality </b>of inland and coastal waters by <b>severely restricting </b>compounds such as dichloromethane or totally phasing out (by 2025) compounds like Hg. Environmental Quality Standard (EQS) for dichloromethane has been set to 20\u03bcg litre<sup>-1</sup>. Any discharge contributing &gt;1% of this level is likely to be scrutinised by the regulatory agency, hence the remediation of aqueous waste streams contaminated with dichloromethane will be difficult and costly.</p><ul><li>Solvent Emissions Directive (SED) (<a href=\"http://rod.eionet.europa.eu/instruments/536\">http://rod.eionet.europa.eu/instruments/536</a>)</li></ul><p>The SED seeks to <b>limit the discharge </b>of VOCs to the environment. Also, the directive seeks to <b>replace</b> the most harmful VOCs.&nbsp; The use of these solvents is still possible <b>with justification</b>, but <b>very tight emission limits</b> apply.</p><ul><li>REACH</li></ul><p>(<a href=\"http://ec.europa.eu/environment/chemicals/reach/reach_en.htm\">http://ec.europa.eu/environment/chemicals/reach/reach_en.htm</a>)</p><p>REACH (Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Restriction of Chemicals) is the European legislation for control of chemicals. It specifies which chemicals must be registered and how; how to evaluate chemical substances and how to restrict access to chemicals that are regarded as especially dangerous for human health or the environment.</p><ul><li>Montreal Protocol</li></ul><p>(<a href=\"http://ozone.unep.org/en/treaties-and-decisions/montreal-protocol-substances-deplete-ozone-layer\">http://ozone.unep.org/en/treaties-and-decisions/montreal-protocol-substances-deplete-ozone-layer</a>)</p><p>The Montreal Protocol was designed to eliminate substances that deplete ozone by reaction with ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) in the stratosphere</p><ul><li>Chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and Halons</li><li>Hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs) e.g. R22</li><li>Hydrobromofluorocarbons (HBFCs)</li><li>Carbon tetrachloride</li><li>Methyl chloroform (1,1,1-trichloroethane)</li><li>Methyl bromide</li><li>Bromochloromethane</li></ul>", "title": "Legislative drivers", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [52]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 144}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1304], "order": 2, "remote_id": 557, "dummy": false, "slug": "case-study-chlorinated-solvents", "order_dirty": true, "text": null, "title": "Case study: Chlorinated solvents ", "dirty": "[]", "changed": false, "lessons": [52]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 145}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1302], "order": 4, "remote_id": 558, "dummy": false, "slug": "case-study-dipolar-aprotic-solvents", "order_dirty": true, "text": null, "title": "Case study: Dipolar aprotic solvents ", "dirty": "[]", "changed": false, "lessons": [52]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 146}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 1, "remote_id": 561, "dummy": false, "slug": "introduction", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>To reduce volumes of solvent used, one simple suggestion is to look at the number and types of solvents used in a synthetic pathway to a target molecule. In a synthetic process, it is fairly typical that a number of different solvents are used &ndash; this causes additional burden (e.g. removing solvent at the end of each step). &nbsp;Counting the number of solvent swaps may identify opportunities where steps could be carried out in succession using the same solvent, without the need to isolate the product (telescoping reactions). (G. Assaf, G. Checksfield, D. Critcher, P. J. Dunn, S. Field, L. J. Harris, et al.,<em> Green Chem.</em>, 2012, <strong>14</strong>, 123). &nbsp;</p>\r\n<p>L. Summerton &amp; A. Constandinou in <em>Green and Sustainable Medicinal Chemistry. Methods, Tools and Strategies for the 21st Century Pharmaceutical Industry</em>, ed.&nbsp; L. Summerton, H. F. Sneddon, L. C. Studies have been carried out to determine whether solvent recovery is viable depending upon factors such as the energy required to achieve this. (M. J. Raymond, C. S. Slater, M. J. Savelski,&nbsp;<em>Green Chem</em>., <strong>2010</strong>, <em>12</em>, 1826) ETH Zurich has also developed an LCA based tool that allows the environmental impact of waste-solvent treatment to be quantified. (http://www.sust-chem.ethz.ch/tools/ecosolvent)</p>\r\n<p>The incineration of spent solvent as opposed to their recovery has been shown to considerably increase the life cycle impacts (C. Jim&eacute;nez-Gonz&aacute;lez, A. Curzons, D. C. Constable, V. Cunningham,<em> Int J LCA</em>, 2004, <strong>9</strong>, 114).&nbsp; However this depends on the complexity of the production of the solvent itself and its boiling point, for solvents such as diethyl ether incineration is a more preferable option than distillation in terms of Total Cumulative Energy Demand (CED). (C. Capello, U. Fischer, K. Hungerbuhler,<em> Green Chem.</em>, 2007, <strong>9</strong>, 927)</p>\r\n<p>Solvent recycling is not as straightforward in API manufacturing as in other industries due to &nbsp;regulatory approval<em>. </em>Where solvent recovery is deemed to be uneconomical, other options include down-cycling the solvent for example for heat recovery or use in other industrial applications.&nbsp; (D. There are a variety of different approaches to alternative solvents currently under investigation, though some are arguably more &lsquo;green&rsquo; than others.&nbsp; &nbsp;All solvent replacement strategies have associated advantages and disadvantages which must be weighed up, and considered within a lifecycle context.&nbsp; Significant issues affecting the uptake of alternative solvents can be associated with not only cost and availability, but also regulation, lack of safety data on newer solvents and insufficient purity levels for use in cGMP manufacturing. (C. P. Ashcroft, P. J. Dunn, J. D. Hayler, A. S. Wells,<em> Org. Process Res. Dev.</em>, 2015, <strong>19</strong>, 740)</p>", "title": "Summary", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_resources\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [57]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 160}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1306, 1320], "order": 1, "remote_id": 595, "dummy": true, "slug": "drivers-towards-whole-process-thinking", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>When considering the sustainability impact of pharmaceuticals, LCA/LCI discussions are often dominated by the impact of chemical synthesis.&nbsp; However, the customers and stakeholders of the pharmaceutical industry &ndash; e.g. the UK National Health Service (NHS), Swedish Medicinal Products Agency &ndash; &nbsp;are keen to focus not only on the environmental impact of the synthesis of the API, but on the whole product process all the way to the finished product delivered to the patient. For example, the pie chart in <strong>Figure 1 </strong>shows the carbon footprint breakdown of the NHS, where the greatest contributing division is procurement &ndash; the goods and services brought in. A more detailed breakdown (the bar chart in Figure 1) indicates that pharmaceuticals are the major contributing factor.</p>\r\n<p>[figure:show:278]</p>\r\n<p><strong>Figure 1: Breakdown of the NHS Carbon footprint by sector for 2012<a title=\"\" name=\"_ftnref1\" href=\"#_ftn1\"><strong>[1]</strong></a></strong></p>\r\n<p>The carbon footprint figures for the NHS in 2004 are shown in Figure 2. &nbsp;By comparing the figures of 2012 to those of 2004, the data suggests that over this time, the carbon contribution of pharmaceuticals has increased by ~20%. This is not as a result of less sustainable manufacturing but is due to the changes in population demographics. The increasing population and an increasing aged population results in a greater demand for services of such organisations. This poses a real dilemma in reducing total carbon footprint in the face of increasing patient numbers and demand (this is covered further under Regulatory &amp; Safety Issues [TODO: link]).</p>\r\n<p>[TODO: figure]</p>", "title": "Drivers towards whole-process thinking", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"type\", \"intro\", \"h5p_resources\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [58]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 161}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1305], "order": 2, "remote_id": 596, "dummy": false, "slug": "challenges-in-effecting-change", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Clearly, one way to reduce carbon footprint is to ask suppliers of products and services to understand and reduce the carbon footprint of the products and services they provide. A barrier to this is cost; with the increase in demand and budget limitations, governments and healthcare providers are also looking to reduce or limit costs. These pricing policies are not only directed towards high volume generic medicines but also new innovative medicines, where the cost is deemed too high for the clinical benefits the patient will receive,&nbsp; despite a new medicine being given a marketing license by the relevant authority (which considers patient safety and efficacy, not cost). As a result, cost has had a significant influence on prescribing policy in recent years.<br />When submitted for marketing authorisation, all medicines need to have an environmental risk assessment (ERA \u2013 covered in more detail in the Regulatory and Safety Issues section- Sections 6-10).&nbsp;</p><p>Currently the ERA is directed towards end-of-life fate of the API in the environment \u2013 the route of manufacture is not considered. However, the ERA tends to be \u2018for information only\u2019, in fact according to the EU directive 2004/27/EC, it is not a criterion upon which a marketing license can be denied. The decision to allow a marketing license depends on the risk/benefit ratio of the medicine to the patient. At the time of writing, no new medicine has failed to get a marketing license due to an unfavourable ERA. For some years in Sweden, data from the ERA has been made available to payers and prescribers in their database (Fass.se).[1] At a high level, Fass.se was designed to promote the prescription of drugs with the lowest environmental fate impact (whilst ensuring that the clinical benefits are equal for the patient).</p><p>For many years, fate in the environment has dominated the LCI of pharmaceuticals, but with carbon footprint and concerns about poor manufacturing practices of suppliers outside of the EU, attitudes are changing and moving towards the development of various ways to reward and promote greener pharmaceutical manufacturing. There have also be efforts to lobby the EU to formalise the consideration of fate and manufacturing practice when considering a license for new pharmaceutical products.[2] Whilst LCI data might not impact on new/novel therapies, especially best in class or first in class (the highest current performance level in an industry, used as a standard or benchmark to be equalled or exceeded)[KP1] , it is being proposed as a measure by which products containing the same API (generic drugs, such as ibuprofen or paracetamol) can be differentiated (Figure 3).</p><p>[TODO: [KP1]Is this two terms and two definitions for the same concept, or two separate terms and two separate definitions? If latter, split into two brackets after each term, or re-write bracket to: (respectively the highest current performance level in an industry, and used as a standard or benchmark to be equalled or exceeded)]</p><p>[figure:show:277]</p><p><strong>Figure 3 The life cycle of a pharmaceutical product, including end of life and potential recycling [TODO: reference]</strong></p>", "title": "Challenges in effecting change", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"type\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [58]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 162}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1308, 1309, 1310], "order": 3, "remote_id": 597, "dummy": false, "slug": "lca-example-1-anti-inflammatory-api", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>In order to understand where carbon footprints and other LCI hotspots are, we can look at the LCA analysis from the API synthesis to the finished product.&nbsp; The first example is an anti-inflammatory API (data provided by CHEM21 member, structure not disclosed).&nbsp; The breakdown of the product formulated as tablets in a simple blister pack is given in Figure 4 (Tools and assumptions given [TODO: link] in appendix). As can be seen, the API synthesis contribution dominates the carbon footprint. This is fairly atypical&nbsp; for an average pharmaceutical product, and reflects the current niche therapeutic area in which the API is used as well as the small production run of 20 tonnes per annum. The manufacturing route is dated and inefficient having been established over thirty years ago. The carbon impact of 354 kgCO<sub>2</sub>e (CO<sub>2</sub>e: carbon dioxide equivalents) per&nbsp;tablet is very high compared to the average pharmaceutical product. Novartis analysis of cradle-to-grave LCA / supply chain carbon footprint reported an average of 10 kgCO<sub>2</sub>e&nbsp;for the annual patient dose of a typical pharmaceutical product.<a title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn1\">[1]</a> To contextualize, this figure of 10 kg CO<sub>2</sub>e per annual patient dose would equate to driving 77 miles in an average car.<a title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn2\">[2]</a> In the UK, CO<sub>2</sub>e for food consumption ranges from 7.2 to 2.8 kg per person per day. Production of 1 kg of beef gives a carbon foot print of ~72 kgCO<sub>2</sub>e.<a title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn3\">[3]</a></p>\r\n<p>[figure:show:279]</p>\r\n<p><strong>Figure 4: Anti-inflammatory API carbon footprint &ndash; original route of manufacture</strong></p>\r\n<p>Redesigning to a more efficient synthetic route to the API gives the carbon footprint shown in Figure 5. This reduces the effective carbon contribution of the API to the tablet from 89% to 77%, but reduces the carbon footprint per tablet from 354 gCO<sub>2</sub> to 166 gCO<sub>2</sub>, thus the benefits of changing the synthetic route are significant with respect to the carbon footprint as a whole. Looking at the contribution of the rest of the secondary manufacturing process, the API still dominates due to the low total annual production. Typically economies of scale work in both primary (synthesis of main product) and secondary (formulation and packaging) manufacturing, but are more pronounced with API manufacture.</p>\r\n<p>[figure:show:280]</p>\r\n<p><strong>Figure 5: Anti-inflammatory API carbon footprint - new route of manufacture</strong></p>\r\n<p>Modelling the process to a production scale of 200 tonnes per annum gives a picture that is more representative of pharmaceuticals produced in higher volumes, with only 48% of the carbon intensity being due to the API synthesis; the contributions of the other inputs in secondary manufacturing are now clearer and can be seen in Figure 6.</p>\r\n<p>[figure:show:281]</p>\r\n<p><strong>Figure 6: Anti-inflammatory API carbon footprint modelled to 200 tonnes per annum of API</strong></p>\r\n<p>&nbsp;</p>", "title": "LCA example 1: anti-inflammatory API", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"intro\", \"type\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [58]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 163}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1311, 1312, 1313, 1314], "order": 4, "remote_id": 598, "dummy": false, "slug": "lca-example-2-selective-1blocker", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>&nbsp;The second example is a selective \u03b2<sub>1</sub>\u2013blocker, prescribed for hypertension and other cardiovascular conditions. In 2011, this medicine was the 19th most commonly prescribed generic medicine, so is a large volume product.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The data below was the output of an LCA study on secondary manufacturing and was supplied by an EFPIA member [TODO: need to reference this better] . The available data is presented in Figure 7 and is a more representative example of most bulk pharmaceutical products.</p><p>[figure:show:282]<br />[figure:show:283]<br />[figure:show:284]<br />[figure:show:285]</p><p><strong>Figure 7 LCA analysis of a \u03b2<sub>1</sub>\u2013blocker production downstream from API</strong></p>", "title": "LCA example 2: selective \u03b21\u2013blocker", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"type\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [58]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 164}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 0, "remote_id": null, "dummy": false, "slug": "secondary-manufacturing", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>It can be seen from the above examples that manufacturing of API and its raw materials contributes ~50% in in each of the areas of: global warming, acidification, photo-oxidant formation and eutrophication. There are therefore many opportunities both in API synthesis and secondary production to lower the overall life cycle impact of pharmaceutical products at point of use.</p>\r\n<p>In secondary manufacturing, a number of areas can be considered for reducing environmental impact:</p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>Technology:Predictive science</li>\r\n<li>New formulations</li>\r\n<li>New packaging</li>\r\n<li>New analytical methodology</li>\r\n<li>More robust processes</li>\r\n<li>Flexible batch/ continuous processing</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n<p><strong>Environmental benefits</strong></p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>Reduced waste</li>\r\n<li>Reduced energy consumption</li>\r\n<li>Reduced emissions\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>During development or production</li>\r\n<li>From patient use</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n</li>\r\n<li>Improved recycling\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>Easier</li>\r\n<li>Less to do</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n</li>\r\n<li>Sustainability</li>\r\n<li>Less solvent usage</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n<p>Detailed analysis of secondary manufacturing is beyond the scope of this module; however it is worth noting a couple of further areas.</p>\r\n<p>For photo-oxidant formation, tablet production is the main source due to high Volatile Organic Compound (VOC) emissions (ethanol) during coating operations. Most EU and US based pharmaceutical manufacturers quote VOC losses (fugitive solvent emissions to air) of between 1-2% of total solvents consumed (most report these figures in annual Corporate Responsibility or environmental reports). Some secondary pharmaceutical manufacturing plants in Asia and the Far East lose 80-100% of the VOC solvents they buy in to the atmosphere. While the solvents used in coating are normally regarded as benign, like ethanol, they can contribute to photochemical oxidant formation.</p>", "title": "Secondary manufacturing", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"json_content\", \"id\", \"h5p_library\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": []}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 165}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 0, "remote_id": null, "dummy": false, "slug": "packaging", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Packaging is another area in which a reduction in the use of materials and moving to more sustainable packaging materials should be considered, Figure 8 below shows an example of excessive packaging use. The packaging is for a one month (28 day) supply of 1.25 mg (API dose) capsules of Ramipril, an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor used for lowering blood pressure. Also, the savings reported by Novartis by reducing secondary manufacturing impact are shown in Figure 9 [TODO: expand this to describe the key findings in the text!].</p>\r\n<p>[figure:show:xx]</p>\r\n<p><strong>Figure 8: 1.25 mg Ramipril packaging&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong>&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>\r\n<p>[figure:show:xx]</p>\r\n<p><strong>Figure 9: Some beneficial improvements reported by Novartis that were gained in focusing on reducing the impact of secondary manufacturing.</strong></p>", "title": "Packaging", "dirty": "[\"intro\", \"type\", \"json_content\", \"id\", \"h5p_library\", \"title\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": []}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 166}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1318], "order": 3, "remote_id": 602, "dummy": false, "slug": "detecting-pharmaceuticals-in-the-environment-pie", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Over the past 30 years analytical instrumentation and methodology have advanced to a point where we are able to detect very low levels of non-natural contaminants in the environment. Increases in detection limits and sensitivity have been driven principally by the development of hyphenated techniques &ndash; LC-MS-MS and extractive concentration methodology such as solid phase extraction, which has enabled detection and quantitation down to nanograms per litre (ng L<sup>-1</sup>) levels and lower.&nbsp;</p>\r\n<p>With around 3000 pharmaceutical products in use worldwide (as well as veterinary products and illicit drugs), a large number of pharmaceutical residues have now been detected in a wide range of environmental matrices. These residues, mainly unchanged APIs but also sometimes degradation products, are principally being detected in water and sludge, but have also been found to be present in organisms like fish and plants. <a title=\"\" name=\"_ftnref1\" href=\"#_ftn1\">[1]</a><sup>,<a title=\"\" name=\"_ftnref2\" href=\"#_ftn2\">[2]</a>,<a title=\"\" name=\"_ftnref3\" href=\"#_ftn3\">[3]</a></sup></p>", "title": "Detecting pharmaceuticals in the environment (PIE)", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"type\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [59]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 167}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1318], "order": 4, "remote_id": 603, "dummy": false, "slug": "impact-of-pie", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>The ability to detect and quantify levels of pharmaceuticals in the environment (PIE) has led to an explosion of interest and scrutiny, as evidenced by the near exponential increase in the number of publications in this area from 1980 to the present day as shown in <strong>Figure 1</strong>. Whilst a number of these publications will be on topics like the manufacture and sustainability of pharmaceuticals, the vast majority are focused on the subject of PIE.</p>\r\n<p>[figure:show:289]</p>\r\n<p><strong>Figure 1: Scifinder&trade; search for pharmaceutical and environmental key words (November 2014)</strong></p>\r\n<p>PIE has also attracted the attention of a large cross section of the stakeholders in the pharmaceutical industry ranging from the producers, regulators, academics, non-governmental organisations (NGO), pressure groups and healthcare providers. Several examples of PIE appearing in both the scientific literature and public media are given below for further reading. Of course it should be noted that as &lsquo;headlines&rsquo; are meant to sell newspapers and media articles, they may not be as objective or scientifically balanced as they could be.However, it is important to be aware of how these issues can be perceived, rightly or wrongly, in the public sphere as this can ultimately impact upon the reputation of a company with further knock-on effects (covered in more detail under Regulatory and Safety issues [TODO: link]).</p>", "title": "Impact of PIE", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"type\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [59]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 168}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 1, "remote_id": null, "dummy": false, "slug": "gate-to-grave", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Typically, &ldquo;cradle-to-gate&rdquo; (basic chemical feedstock&rsquo;s to API) or &ldquo;gate-to-gate&rdquo; (intermediates supplied by external suppliers to API) life cycle analysis looks at the sustainability aspects of manufacturing the API, as touched on in the previous lesson [TODO: link]. this lesson, and the rest of this topic, examines sustainability issues for pharmaceuticals downstream from the API &ndash; the so called &ldquo;gate-to-grave&rdquo; lifecycle. This builds on the synthesis of the API, looking at contributions from formulation, packaging, transport and very importantly, the ultimate fate of the actual API substance in the environment.</p>", "title": "\"Gate to grave\"", "dirty": "[\"intro\", \"type\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_resources\", \"id\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": []}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 169}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 1, "remote_id": 600, "dummy": false, "slug": "secondary-manufacturing", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>It can be seen from the examples in the previous lesson that manufacturing of API and its raw materials contributes ~50% in in each of the areas of: global warming, acidification, photo-oxidant formation and eutrophication. There are therefore many opportunities both in API synthesis and secondary production to lower the overall life cycle impact of pharmaceutical products at point of use.</p>\r\n<p>In secondary manufacturing, a number of areas can be considered for reducing environmental impact:</p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>Technology:Predictive science</li>\r\n<li>New formulations</li>\r\n<li>New packaging</li>\r\n<li>New analytical methodology</li>\r\n<li>More robust processes</li>\r\n<li>Flexible batch/ continuous processing</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n<p><strong>Environmental benefits</strong></p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>Reduced waste</li>\r\n<li>Reduced energy consumption</li>\r\n<li>Reduced emissions\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>During development or production</li>\r\n<li>From patient use</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n</li>\r\n<li>Improved recycling\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>Easier</li>\r\n<li>Less to do</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n</li>\r\n<li>Sustainability</li>\r\n<li>Less solvent usage</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n<p>Detailed analysis of secondary manufacturing is beyond the scope of this module; however it is worth noting a couple of further areas.</p>\r\n<p>For photo-oxidant formation, tablet production is the main source due to high Volatile Organic Compound (VOC) emissions (ethanol) during coating operations. Most EU and US based pharmaceutical manufacturers quote VOC losses (fugitive solvent emissions to air) of between 1-2% of total solvents consumed (most report these figures in annual Corporate Responsibility or environmental reports).</p>\r\n<p>Some secondary pharmaceutical manufacturing plants in Asia and the Far East lose 80-100% of the VOC solvents they buy in to the atmosphere. While the solvents used in coating are normally regarded as benign, like ethanol, they can contribute to photochemical oxidant formation.</p>", "title": "Secondary manufacturing", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [59]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 170}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1315, 1316, 1317], "order": 2, "remote_id": 601, "dummy": false, "slug": "packaging", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Packaging is another area in which a reduction in the use of materials and moving to more sustainable packaging materials should be considered, Figure 8 below shows an example of excessive packaging use.
