"introduction", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>There are three main routes by which pharmaceutical molecules enter the environment, which are shown in <strong>Figure 1:</strong></p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>Through normal patient use</li>\r\n<li>Improper disposal of unwanted pharmaceuticals and related medical devices such as patches, implants etc. into land fill or water courses</li>\r\n<li>Point source pollution at sites of manufacture/formulation</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n<p>A fourth route which is starting to become more prevalent (or at least better detected) is the Illegal or off-label use of pharmaceuticals resulting in accumulation in unintended species like plants and animals.</p>\r\n<p>[figure:show:290]</p>\r\n<h3>Definitions</h3>\r\n<p><strong>Point source pollution</strong></p>\r\n<p>Discharge, intentionally or otherwise, of manufacturing waste containing higher than permitted or safe concentrations of API&rsquo;s into water treatment plants or water courses from a single source.<a title=\"\" name=\"_ftnref1\" href=\"#_ftn1\">[1]</a><sup>,<a title=\"\" name=\"_ftnref2\" href=\"#_ftn2\">[2]</a></sup></p>\r\n<p><strong>Illegal / off-label uses</strong></p>\r\n<p>Off-label uses refer to the permitted use of approved medications for other than their intended indications<a title=\"\" name=\"_ftnref3\" href=\"#_ftn3\">[3]</a> and, combined with illegal usage of drugs, can therefore often lead to the accumulation of API residues in the environment or living organisms where they should not be found. Of course, potential issues with pharmacologically active residues in the environment may also apply to illegal/recreational drugs which are out of the scope of this work.</p>", "title": "Introduction", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"type\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [60]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 172}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 3, "remote_id": 582, "dummy": false, "slug": "normal-human-use", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>After administration, the API maybe excreted unchanged in urine or faeces or metabolised to new chemical entities.&nbsp; These metabolites may or may not be pharmacologically active; an API may give a single metabolite or multiple metabolites that are then excreted.&nbsp; Metabolism usually proceeds via oxidation, reduction or hydrolysis and can be followed by secondary processes such as sulphate formation, glucuronidation etc. Almost all API&rsquo;s and associated metabolites have such a low vapour pressure that loss <em>via</em> the lungs or partition&nbsp; into the atmosphere after getting into water or soil is never observed as a major route into the environment. Thus after dosing, the drug and any metabolites are excreted and thus enter, in the main, into the sewage treatment system where used or directly into the environment if no sewage system is in place.</p>", "title": "Normal human use", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [60]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 173}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1320], "order": 3, "remote_id": 583, "dummy": false, "slug": "improper-disposal", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Unwanted/unused pharmaceuticals are disposed of <em>via</em> direct flushing of tablets etc. into the municipal sewage system or putting tablets into municipal solid waste systems which are usually destined for land fill. Eventually APIs in land fill sites, may leech out and contaminate ground water, although if blister packed or in containers, these would have to degrade first. Other solids like syringes, implants and patches improperly disposed of in land fill could also lead to API contamination of ground water. Industrial waste containing API residues can also be illegally land filled or dumped into water courses to avoid costs associated with proper disposal routes (land fill tax, incineration). An example of the magnitude of unused/unwanted pharmaceuticals is shown for Sweden in 2011 in <strong>Figure 2</strong>.<a title=\"\" name=\"_ftnref1\" href=\"#_ftn1\"></a></p>\r\n<p><strong><strong>[figure:show:291]</strong></strong></p>\r\n<p><strong>Figure 2</strong> <strong>Tonnes of unused/unwanted pharmaceuticals by sector for Sweden in 201</strong>[TODO:??]</p>\r\n<p>Unused medicines arise from a wide range of factors: patients not completing the prescribed course due to improvement in the condition, failure to take due to undesirable side effects, out of date drugs, damaged packaging, and many others. It is debatable as to the extent of the escape of APIs into the environment <em>via</em> this route compared to normal patient use and point source pollution.<a title=\"\" name=\"_ftnref1\" href=\"#_ftn1\">[1]</a></p>", "title": "Improper disposal", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"type\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [60]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 174}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1321, 1322, 1323], "order": 1, "remote_id": 585, "dummy": false, "slug": "pharmaceutical-release-in-context", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>It should be noted that any potential issues with API residues in the environment are common to all xenobiotic (foreign to a living organism) materials released through human activities. Nature does not generally differentiate between API molecules and any other chemical classes. Due to biological activity exhibited by pharmaceuticals such as antibiotics, (oncology drugs in particular), and indeed&nbsp; some undesired activities like endocrine disruption, there has been some debate that pharmaceuticals&nbsp; should be&nbsp; considered as a high area of concern.</p>\r\n<p>However, as pointed out by Taylor <em>et al</em>.<a title=\"\" name=\"_ftnref1\" href=\"#_ftn1\">[1]</a> pharmaceuticals are a small subset of chemicals, and there are thousands of chemicals that have been/are emitted into the environment for which we have no data with respect to their environmental fate, let alone biological activity at the molecular level. Several classes of widely used industrial compounds (phthalates, alkoxy phenols) have been shown to have potent endocrine disrupting potential.</p>\r\n<p>Thus, a chemical that is not classed as an API/or having API-like activity, is not except from having some mechanism of potent biological activity. For example, nitroglycerine, Warfarin and dimethyl fumarate, initially sold respectively as an explosive, a rodenticide and a mould inhibitor have subsequently all been used as pharmaceuticals. To gain some perspective on the scale of release of chemicals into the environment, data for releases of chemicals into the environment in the USA between 2003 and 2013 is shown in <strong>Figure 1.</strong></p>\r\n<p><strong>[figure:show:292][figure:show:293]</strong></p>\r\n<p><strong><strong>Figure 1</strong> <strong>2013 TRI National Analysis: Releases of Chemicals</strong>[2]</strong></p>\r\n<p>In the Toxic Release Inventory (TRI), a &ldquo;release&rdquo; of a chemical generally refers to a chemical that is emitted to the air, discharged to water, or placed in some type of land disposal unit. A closer breakdown for individual industry sectors in 2013 is shown in <strong>Figure 2</strong>.</p>\r\n<p>[figure:show:294]</p>\r\n<p><strong>Figure 2 Breakdown of chemical releases in the USA 2013<a title=\"\" name=\"_ftnref1\" href=\"#_ftn1\"><strong>[1]</strong></a></strong></p>\r\n<p>Pharmaceuticals are a subset of chemicals, but it should be noted that the above data would not include API release into the environment through patient use or improper disposal of unwanted pharmaceuticals. Since TRI focuses on releases from industrial facilities, these figures illustrate that contamination of the environment by chemicals comes from many sources and not just the manufacture and use of pharmaceuticals.</p>", "title": "Pharmaceutical release in context", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"type\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [61]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 175}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 2, "remote_id": 586, "dummy": false, "slug": "possible-pharmaceutical-fates", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Pharmaceuticals are a subset of chemicals, but it should be noted that the above data would not include API release into the environment through patient use or improper disposal of unwanted pharmaceuticals. Since TRI focuses on releases from industrial facilities, these figures illustrate that contamination of the environment by chemicals comes from many sources and not just the manufacture and use of pharmaceuticals.</p>\r\n<p>Once released into the environment, an API or metabolite may be:</p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>Decomposed to innocuous fragments and eventually mineralised &ndash; converted to carbon dioxide, nitrates, sulphates etc.</li>\r\n<li>Decomposed to more recalcitrant fragments that are persistent.</li>\r\n<li>Recalcitrant &ndash; does not decompose- and may or may not show undesirable biological activity.</li>\r\n<li>Bind to organic solids such as soils, river/lake sediments and sludge in sewage treatment plants where it could accumulate or slowly decompose. This binding rapidly reduces the concentration of the API in solution, but may not necessarily remove it from the environment. The extent (efficiency) of binding is dependent on the nature of the solid and thus will be location dependant.</li>\r\n<li>Loss to air is almost never seen for most APIs.</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n<p>Therefore the two main environments are water (major) and land (minor).</p>", "title": "Possible pharmaceutical fates", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [61]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 176}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 3, "remote_id": 587, "dummy": false, "slug": "release-to-water", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Judgements on a chemical substance related to releases to water are based on three main properties &ndash; Persistence, Bioaccumulation &amp; Toxicity (PBT). Any one of these properties may cause a problem, and they are often interactive:&nbsp; two bad properties together may cause significant problems. If all three properties are bad then the substance is probably already regulated if a solvent or chemical, but not necessarily an API.</p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>Persistence (P) &ndash; the compound is recalcitrant and not biodegraded hence will persist in the environment.&nbsp; Persistence is now considered a problem <em>per se.</em></li>\r\n<li>Bioaccumulation (B) &ndash; concentration of materials from water into organisms &ndash; usually in lipids/fats. This property is very difficult and expensive to measure <em>in vivo</em> and usually the octanol/water partition coefficient (K<sub>ow</sub>) is used as a surrogate indicator of bioaccumulation.</li>\r\n<li>Toxicity (T) &ndash; kills or is deleterious to microorganisms/animals. It is worth noting, however, that Endocrine Disruptor (ED) issues are more complicated: toxicity can depend on organism life stage, e.g. infancy vs adulthood. Additionally, toxicity may be indirect, for example: Triggering changes in DNA leading to mutation or the development of enzymes that inactivate antibiotics thereby, whilst not harming the organism directly, can make it more prone to infection or disease.</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n<p>These properties will be discussed later in the Regulatory and Safety Issues section [TODO: link].</p>", "title": "Release to water", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [61]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 177}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 1, "remote_id": 591, "dummy": false, "slug": "techniques-in-use", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Typically, &nbsp;the information on the concentration, distribution and fate of the API in most regulatory ecotoxicity testing experiments used for the required environmental risk assessment (ERA) is determined using quantitative analytical techniques such as&nbsp; LC, LC-MS and use of a <sup>14</sup>C radio labelled API sample with the rate and extent of mineralisation being determined by measuring the evolution of <sup>14</sup>CO<sub>2</sub>. Structures of decomposition products are not normally determined, though many other studies are run and published where decomposition products are semi-quantitated by LC, and punitive structures proposed by LC-MS and LC-MS/MS.<sup>2</sup> It is rare for breakdown products to be isolated and subject to further rigorous structure determination such as NMR Spectroscopy and X-ray Crystallography.</p>\r\n<p>In most cases, the structures are likely to be correct, but caution should be exercised; especially with more complex molecules; as it is rare to see structures of degradation products that have been assigned by spectroscopy, to be validated by independent synthesis of standard materials. The lack of authentic analytical standards also means that many studies on transformation products are not properly quantified. Most studies that investigate the structure of degradation products are run in labs, and thus the decomposition compounds are rarely extracted from environmental samples.</p>\r\n<p>Typically photochemical degradation/oxidation, active sewage sludge, tests with microorganisms etc. are run in labs under conditions that mimic specific environmental conditions and therefore may not reflect the true decomposition pathway in the environment. Occasionally degradation studies are run in water-solvent mixtures or at pH values that would never be reached in the environment. We need to bear in mind that collections of degrading organisms like sewage sludge can vary in composition and activity subject to the location of sampling, time of year and other factors.</p>", "title": "Techniques in use", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [62]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 178}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 4, "remote_id": 588, "dummy": false, "slug": "recalcitrance-of-apis-and-metabolites", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Many API&rsquo;s and their metabolites once excreted from the patient (or in the case of API&rsquo;s discharged into water courses) are recalcitrant to further breakdown, especially in effluent treatment plants/sewage treatment plants (ETP/STP) and natural water courses (rivers, lakes etc.). Considering routes into the environment <em>via</em> the patient, APIs may be excreted unchanged, as mixtures of unchanged API alongside one or several major metabolite(s), or completely metabolised to single or mixtures of metabolite(s).</p>\r\n<p>In the environment, there may be no, partial or full chemical breakdown of the excreted compounds. As with metabolites, breakdown products can be more problematic than the parent compound &ndash; potentially more toxic and more recalcitrant. Many APIs are not removed during typical sewage treatments, but can be absorbed onto sewage sludge.</p>", "title": "Recalcitrance of APIs and metabolites", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [61]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 179}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1333], "order": 5, "remote_id": 589, "dummy": false, "slug": "decomposition-routes", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>In the environment, there are four main decomposition routes for API/API metabolite molecules:</p>\r\n<p>1) Chemical</p>\r\n<p>Typically, simple hydrolysis occurring between pH 5 and 8 &ndash;the pH will depend on the exact aquatic environment.</p>\r\n<p>2) Oxidation by air</p>\r\n<p>Most API molecules are resistant to oxidation by air, but maybe oxidised in the presence of catalysts.</p>\r\n<p>3) Enzymatic (or biotic degradation) &ndash; molecules can be absorbed by microorganisms or higher life forms and metabolised <em>via</em> enzyme catalysis. Xenobiotic materials are metabolised to make them more polar to aid excretion, or to begin a breakdown process to utilise the molecule as a carbon/nitrogen source. These enzymatic transformations tend to follow human metabolism pathways &ndash; oxidation, reduction, hydrolysis and other less common transformations. API molecules may encounter enzyme classes (such as p450s - a superfamily of haemoproteins that catalyse the metabolism of a large number of clinically important drugs<a title=\"\" name=\"_ftnref1\" href=\"#_ftn1\">[1]</a>) common to humans but with different selectivities, and classes of oxidative enzymes not normally utilized in human metabolism. As with humans, there can also be secondary metabolism &ndash; formation of phosphates, sulphates, and glucuronides. It should be noted that occasionally transformations in the environment can reverse the beneficial metabolic transformations in patients; one of the most problematic API molecules, Ethinyl estradiol (EE2) is partly excreted as the soluble glucuronide which does not have estrogenic and endocrine disruption properties. This is converted back in STPs to the parent API which exhibits these undesirable properties, <strong>Figure 1.</strong></p>\r\n<p><strong>[TODO: figure]<br /></strong></p>\r\n<p><strong>Figure 1 Biotic transformations of EE2</strong></p>\r\n<p>4) Photochemical/photochemical oxidation</p>\r\n<p>Direct photolytic decomposition (promotion to an excited state followed by a reaction) requires absorption of natural sunlight by the molecule absorbs (has an absorption maxima &gt;290 nm). If a molecule has a UV/Vis maximum below 290 nm, it may still be decomposed by an indirect photochemical process, through reaction with high energy species like the ROO<sup>.</sup>, OH<sup>.</sup> Radicals and singlet oxygen, which are generated photochemically <em>via</em> dissolved sensitizers based on organic substances like humic acids.</p>\r\n<p>Owing to the stability designed into most pharmaceutical molecules, uncatalysed chemical reactions in the environment may be limited to the hydrolysis of esters and possibly oxidation of highly reactive groups like mercaptans. Chemical transformations will not lead directly to mineralisation, but to a chemical species closely related to the original API which could be resistant to further chemical only transformations. Most APIs are degraded <em>in vivo</em> <em>via</em> enzyme catalysis in microorganisms or <em>in vitro</em> by direct/indirect photochemical pathways.</p>", "title": "Decomposition routes", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"intro\", \"type\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [61]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 180}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1324, 1325, 1326, 1327, 1328, 1329, 1330, 1331, 1332, 1334, 1335], "order": 2, "remote_id": 592, "dummy": false, "slug": "example-molecules", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Listed below are 10 typical pharmaceutical molecules and their breakdown products under conditions likely to be encountered in the environment. A number of treatments collectively called advanced oxidation technologies/processes (AOT/AOP) can be used to treat waste water containing chemicals known to be recalcitrant and/or toxic in biological treatment/sewage treatment plants before discharge into the environment. Decomposition products from AOT/AOP processing have not been included since these technologies operate under harsh oxidative conditions that are never encountered in the environment. APIs may come into contact with milder technologies used to disinfect drinking water, which would lead to partial oxidation.</p><p>Whatever the mode of reaction, unless a molecule is mineralised, it is ill-advised to assume one or two transformations will render a toxic/recalcitrant molecule less so. Transformation may result in products with greater environmental issues than the original molecule.<a href=\"#_ftn1\" title=\"\">[1]</a>,<a href=\"#_ftn2\" title=\"\">[2]</a> Likewise, it is unwise to QUANTIFY the eco-toxicity of breakdown products computationally, e.g. with quantitative structure\u2013activity relationship (QSAR) modelling since:</p><ul><li>It is often inaccurate for the parent pharmaceutical molecules</li><li>The assigned structures for the transformation products could be incorrect.</li><li>An unambiguous answer can only be reached from physical testing.</li></ul><p>The ten molecules have been selected to give examples of APIs across different therapeutic areas and to show examples of biotic, direct and indirect photolytic decomposition. Mainly, primary breakdown products are shown. These could be subject to further degradation processes.</p><h3><strong>1) Diclofenac </strong></h3><p>[figure:show:295]</p><p><strong>Figure 2</strong> <strong>Biotic and photo-degradation routes of diclofenac<a href=\"#_ftn3\" title=\"\"><strong>[3]</strong></a>,<a href=\"#_ftn4\" title=\"\"><strong>[4]</strong></a>,<a href=\"#_ftn5\" title=\"\"><strong>[5]</strong></a>,<a href=\"#_ftn6\" title=\"\"><strong>[6]</strong></a></strong></p><h3><strong>2) Fluoxetine </strong></h3><p>[figure:show:296]</p><p><strong>Figure 3</strong> <strong>Direct and indirect photo-degrdation of Fluoxetine<a href=\"#_ftn7\" title=\"\"><strong>[7]</strong></a></strong></p><h3><strong>3) Paroxetine</strong></h3><p><strong>[figure:show:297]</strong></p><p><strong>Figure 4 Photo-degradation of paroxetine<a href=\"#_ftn8\" title=\"\"><strong>[8]</strong></a></strong></p><p><strong><strong>[figure:show:298]</strong></strong></p><h3><strong>4) Atorvastin</strong></h3><p><strong>[figure:show:299]</strong></p><p><strong>Figure 5 Hydrolysis of Atorvastatin<a href=\"#_ftn9\" title=\"\"><strong>[9]</strong></a></strong></p><h3><strong>5) Fluphenazine</strong></h3><p><strong>[figure:show:300]</strong></p><p><strong>Figure 6</strong> <strong>Photo-degradation of Fluphenazine<a href=\"#_ftn10\" title=\"\"><strong>[10]</strong></a></strong></p><h3><strong>6) Tamoxifen </strong></h3><p><strong>[figure:show:301]</strong></p><p><strong>[figure:show:302]</strong></p><p><strong>Figure 7</strong> <strong>Photodegradation of Tamoxifen<a href=\"#_ftn11\" title=\"\"><strong>[11]</strong></a></strong></p><h3><strong>7)&nbsp; This ERA is based on a defined set of experiments designed to look at the potential effects of the API on three trophic life forms and bacteria, along with other experimentally determined/calculated figures that will give some idea of the <strong>PBT</strong> risk of the API.<a title=\"\" name=\"_ftnref1\" href=\"#_ftn1\">[1]</a></p>\r\n<p>Whilst it is mandatory to submit an ERA, no pharmaceutical product has been refused a license on the grounds of an adverse ERA. Although the ERA data to date would suggest most APIs pose negligible risk to the environment, it has been suggested that this is a reflection on the limitations of the current ERA testing protocol. [REF NEEDED!]</p>\r\n<p>Typically, approval of a new medicinal product by regulatory authorities is subject to unmet clinical/medical need, efficacy, and safety for the patient. However, the granting of a license for a new API does not automatically mean it will become available, since individual states/regions may decide the cost:benefit ratio is insufficient, and will not reimburse for the product drug.</p>\r\n<p>In certain states, some use is made of ERA data, and there are some who consider that the more widespread use of the ERA data is appropriate.</p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>Sweden uses ERA data to drive prescribing and reimbursement towards APIs with more favourable environmental profiles.</li>\r\n<li>Some stakeholders would like to see consideration of the ERA part of the marketing authorisation for new pharmaceutical products (see Benign by Design).</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n<p>The regulatory requirement for an ERA has been in existence since 2006 so for many of the older APIs, no formal ERA data exists although non-regulatory tests may have been performed and published in the open literature.</p>", "title": "The need for environmental risk assessment", "dirty": "[\"intro\", \"type\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [64]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 183}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 2, "remote_id": 610, "dummy": false, "slug": "description-of-era", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>The ERA for an API runs through a number of phases, involving successive levels designed to generate more data if concern around a particular substance increases. effects</p>\r\n</td>\r\n</tr>\r\n</tbody>\r\n</table>\r\n<p>The ERA is principally based around two figures: &nbsp;the calculated Predicted Environmental Concentration (PEC) of the API in the environment (water) and the measured concentration at which no adverse environmental issues would be expected (predicted no effect concentration PNEC). ERAs normally provide information on how the PEC/PNEC figures have been calculated. Many ERAs and the data submitted to regulatory agencies are in the public domain and can be found by searching the FDA/EMA websites (examples below). If looking for a specific API, it is always best to search both generic as well as brand names e.g. Rosuvastatin and Crestor.</p>\r\n<p>Sources for ERA data:</p>\r\n<ol>\r\n<li>http://www.astrazeneca.com/Responsibility/The-environment/Pharmaceuticals-in-the-environment/era-data-2012.</li>\r\n<li>http://www.msds-gsk.com/</li>\r\n<li>www.fass.se</li>\r\n</ol>\r\n<div>&nbsp;</div>", "title": "Description of ERA", "dirty": "[\"intro\", \"type\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [64]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 184}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 1, "remote_id": 624, "dummy": false, "slug": "scope-for-biodegradable-api-molecules", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>One solution put forward to reducing the burden of PIE is to design and market totally biodegradable API molecules. Vaccines, therapeutic enzymes, hormones and biological therapies (termed &lsquo;biologics&rsquo;) like monoclonal antibodies are not subject to ERA, or to as much scrutiny post-patient as small molecule APIs, as they are deemed to be &lsquo;natural&rsquo; and rapidly breakdown in the patient and environment to form small non-toxic materials like amino acids.</p>\r\n<p>This may not always be the case with &lsquo;hybrid molecules&rsquo; such as PEGylated antibodies and antibody drug conjugates. While the number of biological medicines (biologics) in use has risen over the past 10 years, small molecule APIs are still heavily prevalent for treating many diseases.<a title=\"\" name=\"_ftnref1\" href=\"#_ftn1\">[1]</a> This suggests biologics are unlikely to replace small molecules in the near future and for these small molecules, ERA assessment will still be required (see Regulation and Safety [TODO: link]).</p>", "title": "Scope for biodegradable API molecules", "dirty": "[\"intro\", \"type\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": []}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 185}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 2, "remote_id": 625, "dummy": false, "slug": "candidate-failure", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Pharmaceutical drug candidates have a failure rate of 93-96% at the R&amp;D stage, as shown in<strong> Figure&nbsp;1</strong>. Early development failure arises from a range of factors such as inadequate pharmacokinetics, bioavailability and unacceptable toxicology profiles, in addition to lack of efficacy in man. Candidate drug properties, a consequence of chemistry design, are key to the success or failure of a proposed molecule. &nbsp;Hence an additional barrier in the form of designing biodegrable drugs would impact further still on what is already a very high attrition rate.</p>\r\n<p>[TODO: figure]</p>\r\n<p>&nbsp;</p>", "title": "Candidate failure", "dirty": "[\"intro\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"type\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [65]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 186}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 3, "remote_id": 626, "dummy": false, "slug": "questions-around-green-design", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>One solution to potential PIE issues with new pharmaceuticals is &lsquo;Green Design&rsquo;; the concept of producing drugs with (near) zero environmental impact i.e. ones that exhibit no persistence, bioaccumulation or toxicity. This poses a number of questions however:</p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>Could we &lsquo;Design Green&rsquo; without compromise to patient benefit?</li>\r\n<li>Could it apply to all or only some therapies?</li>\r\n<li>Would we want to &lsquo;Design Green&rsquo;? Given the difficulty and large numbers of existing hurdles (Figure 1) in getting new pharmaceuticals to market and hence the patient, why would medicinal chemists add further barriers such as designing molecules for degradation post patient?</li>\r\n<li>When would &lsquo;green benefit&rsquo; emerge?</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n<p>Developing general guidelines is difficult. Lipinski&rsquo;s famous rule of five describes the desirable &lsquo;drug like&rsquo; properties of a molecule:<a title=\"\" name=\"_ftnref1\" href=\"#_ftn1\">[1]</a></p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>No more than 5 hydrogen bond donors.</li>\r\n<li>Not more than 10 hydrogen bond acceptors</li>\r\n<li>A&nbsp;molecular mass less than 500 Da</li>\r\n<li>An octanol/water partition coefficient log <em>P </em>of no greater than 5</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n<p>At present, a similar guideline for avoiding PBT properties in API molecules does not exist. It is also worth noting that guidelines are not rules &ndash; many successful API molecules do not conform to the Lipinski rule of five. Currently, whether or not an API molecule is PBT, is down to chance, and not a factor of molecular design. A number of strategies to avoid PBT have been put forward for consideration during the molecular design phase, and these will be discussed further.</p>", "title": "Questions around green design", "dirty": "[\"intro\", \"type\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [65]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 187}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 5, "remote_id": 627, "dummy": false, "slug": "example-glufosfamide", "order_dirty": true, "text": "", "title": "Example: Glufosfamide", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [65]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 188}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 3, "remote_id": 611, "dummy": false, "slug": "areas-of-concern", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>In the previous section, we outlined the requisite testing in order to assess the likelihood of an API being harmful to the environment. Many pharmaceutical companies carry out and publish studies above and beyond those needed from a regulatory requirement. The regulatory requirement focuses mainly on the fate of the API in the aqueous environment, which is where pharmaceutical residues are most likely destined. Even for aquatic fate, the current ERA testing has its limitations:</p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>Testing APIs for all possible scenarios and all species is not feasible.</li>\r\n<li>Testing is carried out mainly on an API molecule that may pass through the patient unchanged and enter the environment, or be extensively metabolised to other species which are not actually tested [TODO: check this sentence with AW].<a title=\"\" name=\"_ftnref1\" href=\"#_ftn1\">[1]</a></li>\r\n<li>Testing examines the gross effects and not the non-lethal effects, at the molecular level. One criticism of the current ERA testing is that the tests were designed for looking at acute lethal effects of bulk industrial chemicals, and therefore some of the more subtle non-lethal effects of pharmaceuticals need more sophisticated testing. However, many industrial chemicals show effects like endocrine disruption (alkyl stannanes, Bisphenol A, bis-alkyl phthalates) which are not necessarily addressed by the standard ERA tests.<a title=\"\" name=\"_ftnref2\" href=\"#_ftn2\">[2]</a>&nbsp;</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\r\n<p>Regarding potential human health issues, a number of oestrogenic residues like ethinyl estradiol (EE2) are known to be very toxic, but for most APIs the risk to human health is considered negligible in a high quality drinking water source.<a title=\"\" name=\"_ftnref3\" href=\"#_ftn3\">[3]</a><sup>,<a micro-contaminants are high, as shown in Table 1.Unfortunately, access to high quality, pure drinking water is not a universal human benefit, and serious issues can arise if drinking water sources "model": "repo.question", "pk": 195}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 0, "remote_id": null, "dummy": false, "slug": "growth-in-legislation", "order_dirty": true, "text": "", "title": "Growth in legislation", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"json_content\", \"id\", \"h5p_library\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": []}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 196}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1477], "order": 0, "remote_id": 617, "dummy": false, "slug": "current-situation", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>[TODO: can Andy record a narration for this?]</p>", "title": "Current situation", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"type\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [68, 30]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 197}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [1336, 1337, 1338, 1339], "order": 0, "remote_id": 618, "dummy": false, "slug": "concerns-and-proposed-future-approaches", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>In an ideal situation, an API molecule would be stable during processing and formulation, stable for many years at a range of temperatures and humidities, active and efficacious when taken by the patient; and then be completely metabolised or decomposed in the environment on excretion, into innocuous substances. For more information, see the section on Benign by Design [TODO: link]. In practice, this is very difficult to achieve and represents somewhat of a utopian situation; this is now being recognised by the stakeholders in the pharmaceutical industry. If some APIs can be designed in that way in the future, it would represent an ideal scenario but is very unlikely to be the case for all small molecules.</p>\r\n<p>Additionally of course, it would not solve the issue of the persistence of many of the current treatments, which will continue to be used for the foreseeable future.&nbsp; One obvious course of action to remove human exposure at least, would be to upgrade the water/sewage treatment plants to remove the API residues (or other residues like estrogens). This would come at a cost, Sweden for example, would incur the additional cost of &euro;20\u2011 150 per person per year, for such an upgrade.</p>\r\n<p>Switzerland is one of the first countries to start implementing a national policy to reduce micro pollutants in the effluents of municipal sewage treatment plants and estimates a cost of CHF 86 (US$ 63) per household.<a title=\"\" name=\"_ftnref1\" href=\"#_ftn1\">[1]</a> However, looking at the PIE issues from a patient&rsquo;s perspective, there does not appear to be a great deal of awareness regarding more eco-friendly medicines, nor a willingness to pay more for more environmentally benign medicines<a title=\"\" name=\"_ftnref2\" href=\"#_ftn2\">[2]</a> , as shown in <strong>Figure 1</strong>.</p>\r\n<p>[figure:show:307]<br />[figure:show:308]</p>\r\n<p>Dohle <em>et al</em>. found that&ndash;predictably&ndash; for the patient, the balance between environment and effectiveness was very much driven by the severity of the disease/condition being treated:<a title=\"\" name=\"_ftnref1\" href=\"#_ftn1\">[1]</a></p>\r\n<p><em>&lsquo;In the domain of pharmaceuticals used in human medicine, we found that people were willing to consider environmental consequences when choosing a drug, but only when choices were made about treatment options for a rather harmless disease. In contrast, when decisions were made about treatment options for a severe disease, the drug</em><em>&rsquo;</em><em>s effectiveness was the most important criterion. </em><em>Conclusions: </em><em>It can be concluded that the environmental impact of a drug will be hardly considered in decisions about pharmaceuticals for severe diseases like cancer, and this may be due to the fact that these decisions are predominantly affective in nature. However, for less severe health risks, people are willing to balance health and environmental considerations.&rsquo; <br /></em></p>\r\n<p>Looking at stakeholders other than patients, the urgency of the problem and impetus to act increases as you move closer to the industry most likely to be impacted by any legislation for example, in the water industry to remove pollutants like EE2<strong>, Figure 2</strong>.<a title=\"\" name=\"_ftnref2\" href=\"#_ftn2\">[2]</a></p>\r\n<p>[figure:show:309]</p>\r\n<p><strong>Figure 2 Stakeholders perception of PIE</strong></p>\r\n<p>An examination of the various measures to reduce the burden of PIE shows that there is some regional variation on the ranking of various remedies; however correct disposal, development of more eco-friendly products and environmental classification are all close to the top of the lists<sup>4</sup>, as indicated by <strong>Table 1</strong>. As a point of interest, eco-labelling was not deemed a significant measure by those surveyed.<strong> <br /></strong></p>\r\n<p><strong>Table 1 National breakdown of stakeholders options on how to deal with PIE issues</strong></p>\r\n<p><strong>[figure:show:310]</strong></p>", "title": "Concerns and proposed future approaches", "dirty": "[\"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"type\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [68]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 198}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 6, "remote_id": 613, "dummy": false, "slug": "proposed-changes-to-era", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>A recent publication by a group of academics from the UK and Sweden has recommended ten changes to the regulatory ERA.<a title=\"\" name=\"_ftnref1\" href=\"#_ftn1\">[1]</a> These are:</p>\r\n<p>1. Require environmental risk assessment also for products put on the market before 2006. &nbsp;</p>\r\n<p>The recommendations were to perform ERA on products retrospectively (i.e. for drugs that were granted a marketing license before the EMA guidelines came into force) to provide relevant information on APIs that could potentially be found in the environment.</p>\r\n<p>2. Add requirements to assess the risk for development of antibiotic resistance</p>\r\n<p>The researchers recommended that the ERA should also include information enabling assessment of the increased risk of antibiotic resistance development to allow for a more accurate representation of the health risks associated with PIE.</p>\r\n<p>3. Perform only one environmental risk assessment per active pharmaceutical ingredient.</p>\r\n<p>It was recommended that only one ERA needed to be performed per API as opposed to each pharmaceutical company having to perform an ERA for the same molecule in order to acheive consistency and reduce the need for duplication of work and animal testing.</p>\r\n<p>4. Refine the tiered approach&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>\r\n<p>The authors recommended that the tiered approach be refined to include pharmacological, toxicological, and bioconcentration data from the drug discovery process. The result being an improved prioritization process in which ecotoxicity testing can be focused on the most problematic substances and the most relevant test species.&nbsp;</p>\r\n<p>5. Perform mixture toxicity assessments on active pharmaceutical ingredients with similar modes of action</p>\r\n<p>The recommendation was that the ERA should be carried out on groups of APIs, with similar modes of action to improve accuracy.</p>\r\n<p>6. Mandate use of all available ecotoxicity studies</p>\r\n<p>All reliable and relevant ecotoxicity studies should be included to ensure that all important information was considered, thereby enabling informed decisions.</p>\r\n<p>7. Include environmental risks in the risk-benefit analysis</p>\r\n<p>Inclusion of the environmental risks in the risk-benefit analysis for a candidate was recommended, which would encourage the pharmaceutical companies to perform such assessments on time.</p>\r\n<p>8. Require review of the environmental risk assessments at regular intervals</p>\r\n<p>It was recommended that as new, significant environmental information becomes available, ERAs should be updated accordingly to bring forward regulatory use of new data, which would increase collaboration between stakeholders.</p>\r\n<p>9. Include data from production of active pharmaceutical ingredients and formulations in the environmental risk assessments</p>\r\n<p>API discharges from manufacturing (not just the API itself) should be included in the ERA to cover a wider area of the LCA responsible for the highest environmental concentrations detected.</p>\r\n<p>10. Increase transparency</p>\r\n<p>It was recommended that ERA and manufacturing information be made available to the public domain to both make that information available for the purposes of further reach in this field and provide further incentives for companies to take more environmental responsibility throughout their entire supply chains.</p>", "title": "Proposed changes to ERA", "dirty": "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>A number of suggestions to increase the chances that an API molecule htat will not be persistent have been put forward and if the UV maxima is &lt; 290 nm, direct photolysis would not be expected to occur (although indirect photolysis might).</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n<p>However none of the above solutions would be practical or desirable as design options in medicinal chemistry. branched alkanes &gt; low molecular weight aromatics &gt; cyclic alkanes</li>\r\n<li>Saturates &gt; light aromatics &gt; high molecular weight aromatics &gt; polar compounds</li>\r\n<li>Electron-rich aromatics&gt;aromatics with electron withdrawing groups &gt;heterocycles</li>\r\n<li>Substituted aromatics ortho&gt; para&gt; meta</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n<p>&nbsp;</p>", "title": "Non-functionalised hydrocarbon \u2013 like structures", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [70]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 204}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 4, "remote_id": 630, "dummy": false, "slug": "functionalised-molecules", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Scheringer <em>et al</em>. examined ~95,000 compounds for PBT properties with the thresholds defined under REACH.<a title=\"\" name=\"_ftnref1\" href=\"file:///Z:/CHEM21/Education%20and%20Training%20Material/Topic%206/Report%20Breakdown/Chapter%2011_SAS.docx#_ftn1\">[1]</a> Some data was experimental but most was obtained by modelling (QSAR). Depending on which data set the chemicals were taken from, between 3-5% of the total were classified as potentially PBT. The most common structural motifs noted in the PBT set are listed below alongside a comparison with common functionality found in pharmaceutical molecules. Two or more of these structural elements are frequently found in the PBT hazard class of chemicals identified.</p>\r\n<p>[TODO: figure]</p>\r\n<p>It can be seen from the above analysis, that some motifs with high alert for PBT are never or rarely seen in APIs, but some are very common like aliphatic branched amines and ethers.&nbsp; Generally, if there is a choice, in the case of amines, ethers and alcohols, the biotic degradation will favour: primary &gt;secondary &gt;tertiary, and steric hindrance and branching around heteroatom centres are liable to greatly reduce the rates of breakdown. Spiro compounds are also worthy of note, whilst they are not common in API molecules at present, there is a growing interest in using more spiro fragments and as such spiro compounds may therefore become more prevalent in the future. &nbsp;&nbsp;</p>", "title": "Functionalised molecules", "dirty": "[\"intro\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"type\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [70]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 205}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 5, "remote_id": 631, "dummy": false, "slug": "fluorination", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>Another major area for consideration is fluorination; looking at the percentage of halogens&nbsp;introduced into aromatic rings during API synthesis in <strong>Figure 4</strong>, nearly all fluorine and some chlorine are retained in the final API molecule. Traditionally, all bromine and iodine that is introduced, is later removed in the synthesis as these elements are only used as a synthetic handles.</p>\r\n<p>[TODO: figure]</p>\r\n<p>This picture is beginning to change somewhat, with a few more brominated and iodinated aryl APIs being launched. Generally biotic degradation follows the trend: &nbsp;I&gt;Br&gt;Cl&gt; F, with organoiodides also being prone to photo-degradation. Fluorinated compounds are very common; 15-30% of API portfolios consisting of fluorinated molecules. Fluorine is often chosen for the specific beneficial properties it lends to API molecules and is unlikely to disappear from small molecule API portfolios in the near future, if ever. Of course there is some degree of variation year on year, but the overall trend seems to be increasing the mix of aliphatic C-F and CF<sub>3 </sub>&nbsp;units alongside the more traditional sp<sup>2</sup> C-F aryl and heteroaryl fluorides, as shown in <strong>Figure 5</strong>. Typically organofluorine compounds are resistant to biotic breakdown and polyfluorination leads to highly hydrophobic molecules that have a tendency to bioaccumulate. CF<sub>3</sub>-containing molecules may generate the persistent molecule CF<sub>3</sub>CO<sub>2</sub>H if mineralisation occurs.</p>\r\n<p>Despite this, it remains fairly inconceivable that small molecule drugs will be produced in the future without fluorine, tertiary amines, heterocycles etc.</p>\r\n<p>[TODO: figure]</p>", "title": "Fluorination", "dirty": "[\"intro\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"type\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [70]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 206}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 6, "remote_id": 632, "dummy": false, "slug": "summary", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>To summarise, some steps that can be taken to minimise PBT issues with candidate drugs are listed below:</p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>Avoid polyhalogenated fragments (F, Cl, &nbsp;Br).</li>\r\n<li>Avoid fluorine if at all possible.</li>\r\n<li>Avoid large numbers of fused aromatic rings.</li>\r\n<li>If possible, the use of aliphatic rings is preferable to benzene/heteroaromatic rings .</li>\r\n<li>Highly substituted aromatic rings can be problematic.</li>\r\n<li>Avoid highly branched aliphatics.</li>\r\n<li>Avoid highly hindered/quaternary carbons if possible.</li>\r\n<li>Spiro compounds &ndash; be alert.</li>\r\n<li>Esters are preferable to amides</li>\r\n<li>For amides, primary&gt;secondary&gt;tertiary</li>\r\n<li>Ureas are preferable to sulphonamides</li>\r\n<li>High aqueous solubility</li>\r\n<li>As low K<sub>ow</sub> as feasible</li>\r\n<li>Aim for as low a molecular weight as possible</li>\r\n<li>It is beneficial if the compound has a UV/Vis maxima &gt; 290 nm</li>\r\n<li>Use ecotoxicity testing earlier on in the development pipeline to highlight potential environmental issues.</li>\r\n<li>Use predictive tools, but understand their limitations &ndash;probably quite good for P and B &ndash; not reliable for T (for quantitative measures of ecotoxicity) &ndash; some links are provided below.</li>\r\n<li>Look for structural similarity with compounds known to have PBT issues</li>\r\n<li>Look for plausible degradation pathways that lead to known PBT fragments.</li>\r\n<li>Make use of &ldquo;read across&rdquo; data but understand the associated risks and limitations.</li>\r\n</ul>", "title": "Summary", "dirty": "[\"intro\", \"type\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\", \"h5p_resources\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [70]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 207}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 7, "remote_id": 633, "dummy": false, "slug": "predictive-tools", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>A selection of predictive tools are listed below. Some are collections or suites of publically available tools. The tools listed below are representative and not a comprehensive list of what is available</p>\r\n<p><strong>ECOSAR</strong></p>\r\n<p><a href=\"http://www.epa.gov/oppt/newchems/tools/21ecosar.htm\">http://www.epa.gov/oppt/newchems/tools/21ecosar.htm</a></p>\r\n<p>The Ecological Structure Activity Relationships (ECOSAR) class program is a predictive software program system that estimates aquatic toxicity.&nbsp;</p>\r\n<p><strong>EPA Sustainable Futures</strong></p>\r\n<p><a href=\"http://www.epa.gov/oppt/sf/\">http://www.epa.gov/oppt/sf/</a></p>\r\n<p>A suite of links to free tools and training materials</p>\r\n<p><a href=\"http://www.epa.gov/oppt/sf/pubs/index.htm#case\">http://www.epa.gov/oppt/sf/pubs/index.htm#case</a></p>\r\n<p>Published data and examples</p>\r\n<p><strong>Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite</strong></p>\r\n<p><a href=\"http://www.epa.gov/opptintr/exposure/pubs/episuite.htm\">http://www.epa.gov/opptintr/exposure/pubs/episuite.htm</a></p>\r\n<p>The EPI (Estimation Programs Interface) Suite&trade; ", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [22]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 253}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 1, "remote_id": 691, "dummy": false, "slug": "solvents-of-concern", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p>At the screening level, as broad a range of solvents as possible will be utilised to determine ideal conditions such as solubility, reaction temperature (as determined by boiling point), partition coefficient <em>etc</em>. (C. R. McElroy, A. Constantinou, L. C. Jones, L. Summerton, J. H. Clark,<em> Green Chem.</em>, 2015, <strong>17</strong>, 3111)&nbsp; The use of a full solvent set will indicate which classes of solubilising agents give best results and what solvent properties dominate the solvent effects.&nbsp;</p>\r\n<p>However researchers should be aware of solvents that have been categorised as highly hazardous or worse and their use should be avoided even during screening reactions.&nbsp; The highly hazardous classifications can be due to health, safety or environmental reasons as well as regulatory constraints.&nbsp; In <a href=\"http://pubs.acs.org/paragonplus/submission/oprdfk/oprdfk_scope.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">their editorial policy</a>, the journal Organic Process Research and Development discourages research conducted using &lsquo;strongly undesirable solvents&rsquo; such as benzene, carbon tetrachloride, chloroform, HMPA, carbon disulphide.</p>\r\n<p>Solvents that fall into this category include (D. Prat, J. Hayler, A. Wells,<em> Green Chem.</em>, 2014, <strong>16</strong>, 4546)):</p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>Carcinogenic solvents e.g. benzene, 1,2-dichloroethane (H350).</li>\r\n<li>Ozone depleting solvents e.g. Carbon tetrachloride (H420).</li>\r\n<li>Chloroform, due to its toxicity.</li>\r\n<li>Diethyl ether, due to the safety risks associated with its low flash point; low boiling point; resistivity; ability to form peroxides and low auto-ignition temperature.</li>\r\n<li>Nitromethane, due to its high energy of decomposition.</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n<p>Dipolar aprotic solvents are another class of solvents that are subject to an increasing amount of scrutiny.&nbsp; N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc) and 1-Methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) have all been named as substances of very high concern (SVHC) on <a href=\"http://echa.europa.eu/candidate-list-table\">the REACH Candidate list for Authorisation</a></p>\r\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\r\n<p>&nbsp;</p>", "title": "Solvents of concern", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"json_content\", \"h5p_library\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [85]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 254}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 3, "remote_id": 692, "dummy": false, "slug": "other-issues", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<ul>\r\n<li>Process safety</li>\r\n<li>Worker safety and health</li>\r\n<li>Regulatory guidelines &ndash; Environmental Quality Standard (EQS) for dichloromethane has been set to 20&mu;g litre<sup>-1</sup>. Any discharge contributing &gt;1% of this level is likely to be scrutinised by the regulatory agency, hence the remediation of aqueous waste streams contaminated with dichloromethane will be difficult and costly.</p>", "title": "Water Framework Directive (WFD)", "dirty": "[\"type\", \"h5p_resources\", \"h5p_library\", \"title\", \"json_content\"]", "changed": false, "lessons": [86]}, "model": "repo.question", "pk": 256}, {"fields": {"byline": "", "files": [], "order": 2, "remote_id": 695, "dummy": false, "slug": "solvent-emissions-directive-sed", "order_dirty": true, "text": "<p><a href=\"ttp://rod.eionet.europa.eu/instruments/536\">The SED</a> seeks to <strong>limit the discharge </strong>of VOCs to the environment. However a more strategic approach should take into consideration the following:</p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>Inert under reaction conditions</li>\r\n<li>Chemistry must work!</li>\r\n<li>Isolation/work-up/crystallisation</li>\r\n<li>Safety and operability</li>\r\n<li>Human health issues</li>\r\n<li>Can the solvent be recovered/recycled?</li>\r\n<li>Can wastes be incinerated/treated?</li>\r\n<li>Environment and legislation compliance</li>\r\n<li>Overall cost burden to final product</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n<p>Design of Experiments (DoE) and Principal Component Analysis &nbsp;(PCA) can be used as tools to identify solvents to screen, and assist in decision making when looking for replacement solvents.
